title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Nope, sorry. I liked the original Civilization from the early 90's. This effort though technically better with a lot more content, just falls flat. It has none of the charms of Civ 1, in fact I found Civ 3 to be dull and tedious.
The UI simply stank. One simple reason for this is it not allowing you the standard "right click to DESELECT unit". So you always had a unit selected - and as a result often clicked somewhere on the map and off it went, moving to that spot when you did not want it to. So you go to correct it. You click said wrong move unit, but no...... can't select it because of "this unit has already moved", BUT what then happens is ANOTHER unit has become active, which the map did not autocentre on (so you had no idea it had automatically selected another unit), and it then starts with unwanted movement!
You probably don't understand all that - it's hard to put into words. But the terrible UI had me constantly wrong moving entire chains of units all over the place.
The UI is very "non-standard" and it is difficult to get any information regards anything conveniently. There isn't even a proper world map view - the only one you get is a tiny thumbnail sized map that is just a jumbled mess of colours.
You never know where the enemy is. You never know where anything is. You never have the "big picture". You never feel in control. You are constantly fighting your own ministers who are obsessed with building unneeded and extremely expensive "wonders" in every city!
Then comes the AI sides. Even on easiest level and lowest aggression, they just all gang up on you. They all stroke each other peckers, but give you the cold shoulder, refusing all diplomatic requests you make - and never offering any treaties or trades to you. They only contact you with one or two unfair tech trades at the start, and from then on it's only to make bullying demands and declare war. They all share techs and treaties with each other though - with great gusto!
Once one inevitably decides to go to war against you, ALL the others follow suit within the next few turns. They never go to war with each other.
All AI civs are also BRUTALLY, profanely cheating, expansionists. This kind of AI is anathema to my usual style and I loathe and detest it. In Civ 3 this AI style is *all* you get....... every game ends the same after 100-200 turns, no matter how aggressively you try to expand, the AI teams just fills up the whole world with one giant "anti-YOU" alliance and all declare war and crush you.
This unfairness ruins Civ III. I just had to quit/uninstall in frustration. 
The graphics are also rather bland, nay, downright ugly - the civ leader portraits are a joke - and the music is awful.

Extremely disappointing, I expected so much more from this game. Lets not mince words, I loathed it.

And as for 99% of the reviewers around here thinking the sun shines out this game's arse, well they're wrong! It shows how intelligent these reviewers are when hundreds of them are spam that just say "relaxing", "gud game", "is fun", "classic" - hell, one spam review even just said "."! Others tell outright LIES such as "every game is different"...... no every game ends in the cheating AI civs all ganging up on you.

It's reviews like these that fool people into wasting their money on dog shit like Civ 3!

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: There are new, better, and more exciting games out there. So if you prefer that, then this game isn't for you. However, if you really like old classic games, then this is a good one to have. What I like about this old relic is the simple, slow paced, and somewhat out-dated game play. The graphics and special features are no longer advanced by today's standards, but they're still good enough to capture your imagination. The game starts of slow, but gets more exciting as the game advances. Interestingly, the beginning and most boring part of the game is the most critical. If you're like me and prefer to dominate through military force, every action matters. The most satisfying part of the game is proving your superiority by conquering other civilizations, especially when the AI gangs up on you. Be warned: Don't start what you can't finish. AI players love to gang up on human players.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: As a fan of civilization games as a whole, I cannot recommend this game enough. It is definitely my favorite civ game out of the three I have played, (civ 3, civ 5, and civ 6). The only bad thing I can say about this game is that it has a ton of bugs on modern hardware, and often outright crashes for any number of reasons or for no reason at all. I would recommend that if you play you should save a lot and don't try modding unless you are very confident in your hardware's ability to run this game. This game is also insanely hard even on the lowest difficulty. If you are not a fan of hard games, or you have never played a civ game before, then you should play civ 5 or civ 6, two much easier and fair games. Overall this game is a timeless classic and if you can handle the bugs and difficulty, it may just become your favorite civ game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Very easy to get into, not too basic but not too complex and is very fun for first timers, all the extra maps and scenarios provide a lot of extra gameplay past just the default "New Game" option. If you try to just use intuition and not rely on guides or videos, it can be very rewarding when you raise the difficulty bar from "Easiest" to "Warlord"!

What I don't like about it is the mild RNG aspect but that's like reality, you're not always going to have favourable conditions in your country and it's your job to find a work-a-round. Sometimes it works in your favour though, I consider it a challenge. Games can get pretty slow late game though and can be a big time investment but if that's your thing, that's all the better.

9/10

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Best Civilization game in my opinion.
 It has lots of mods, none of the simplistic, casual-like style of the games that came after it, and a relatively good mutliplayer. The art style still retains that design of late 1990's, early 2000's aesthetic. It doesn't try to be cartoony and I love that. Unfortunately later Civ games were less lucky with that.

After more 10 years, here it stood the test of time....

You can't go wrong with the price of it now. All expansions included and no DLC's or anything. A problem that Civ IV, V and VI face. Well worth your money.

 This is a classic strategy game.

The only thing I feel is lacking is the necessity for a full OST in Steam in a downloadble format! The music is amazing. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LYHbIo-WL8c

Update: They made Civilization III's multiplayer work on Steam without Gamespy (since that is now dead). Therefore cannot recommend Civ 3 enough compared.
If only Civ 3 had a remastered version.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This review is in English and Slovak language:
Táto recenzia je v Anglickom a Slovenskom jazyku:

I have been playing the mother of all strategies continuously since 1993 and gradually I went through all her titles and subtitles to V. part. Civilization III. became my longest playing heart affair and I was very reluctant to say goodbye to it as I slowly moved on to the V. part. Personally, I think that III. the part is far better than IV., V. and probably VI., but it is a bit outdated and does not offer such a range of gameplay options. What makes it unique, however, is that this is the last Cvilization where you have the opportunity to create truly gigantic empires with countless armies on large maps.

Matku všetkých stratégií hrám nepretržite už od roku 1993 a postupne som si prešiel všetkými jej titulmi aj podtitulmi až po V. diel. Civilizácia III. sa stala mojou najdlhšie hranou srdcovou záležitosťou a len veľmi nerád som sa s ňou lúčil, keď som pomaly prešiel na V. diel. Osobne si myslím, že III. diel je ďaleko lepší ako IV., V. a asi aj VI., ale je už trocha zastaralý a neponúka takú škálu možností v rámci hrateľnosti. Unikátnym ho však robí to, že je to posledný diel, kde máte možnosť vytvoriť naozaj gigantické impéria s nespočetným množstvom armády na veľkých mapách.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: Not as good as civ 2.  All the AI's follow the same pattern of growth, goals and personality.  Whether they like you or not they will attack you if their army is better than yours so diplomacy is redundant (and they know the exact details of your army).  The AI's also know the full map including where your cities are and where is best to build, so that's annoying.  However I like to run this in the background when I'm playing other games so I don't get board.  Worth about the 0.79p I paid for it.  If you liked civ 2 don't bother buying this game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
[h1]Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36214917/]Curator Group for more reviews[/url][/h1]
Sid Meier's Civilization III holds classic status for a lot of people, and for good reason. Given its age, it holds up suprisingly well. If this review was only comparing it to its contemporaries, Civilization III would get a perfect score. Unfortunately, when compared to later Civilization games, it begins to falter. The biggest knock against Civilization III isn't really an issue with the game, its just that later games build on its foundation so well. Now that we are on the 6th game in the franchise, there is an entry for everyone. If people want the most modern, sleek, and optimized version of Civilization, they can play 6. If they want an old school feel they can play 4. And if they want a sort of middle ground, the 5th game does a great job balancing those 2 elements. For Civilization III, it plays a lot like Civ 4 but with some pretty popular mechanics missing. To me, Civ 3 doesn't really have a niche that it excels at, and that's why I can't recommend it. Every feature is done better in a different Civ game, leaving little reason for me to revisit it 20 years later.

5/10

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: The perfect game to keep your hands busy while listening to a podcast or something. I loved this game as a kid, even though I was terrible at it, and I'm still terrible. I think this game has a good amount of detail without being overly complicated. I'm usually not into strategy games, but I love the sense of mystery as I discover new areas and resources and find the perfect spot to place my next city. I also love how subtly cruel the AI characters are, but it's a little sad that it usually turns to war in the end. Lately, I turn off the domination victory so I'm less stressed about building my population and wiping out enemies, and so I'm more inclined to build diplomatic relationships. I also love the vast number of options for countries to play as, and the unique bonuses they each get. An absolute banger of a game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
So I first want to preface this that I am baised against this game. This is one of the very first game I ever watched some one play and I have very fond memories of sitting next to my dad watching him play this game for hours so it has a very special place in my heart.

Now that being said this game is the Civilization game you should play if your interested in a aggressive empire building strategy where you want to win through domination or by conquering every other nation in the game. From what I've heard civ six and five kind of drop the war aspect and I can tell form experience that Civ fours military strategy is kind of lacking when compared to civ three. This is in part due to later games kind of getting rid of the "special unit". In civ three every nation has a unique unit that only they can build and each one of them is differrent and offers an improvement over the regular version any other nation can unlock. These units can be a complete game changer for you and your conquest and thus choosing which nation to play as is beyond important as you have to decide about important factors such as what do you wan as a special unit and does it come to late for it to make a differrence in my game.  This game has solid graphics for the time it came out and very good music. 
As all other civ games it's a very good and fun strategy game where you can sink hours into with out even realizing.  
To sum up I would recommend this Civilization game for two reasons one its currently the cheapest on steam and it has to best combat strategy. The later game kind of abandon this part of the game. So if your looking for an empire building game and are interested in nothing else then conquering and destroying every other nation then this is the civ game for you.  If not I would recommend you look at the later civ games.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: This is the quintessential turn-based strategy game of my youth. So much has been said and loved on the newer Civilization games, but I find myself always gravitating back to this gem. It's older, not as shiny, and certainly buggy at times, but man does it nail the world building, gameplay, and joy that comes from building an empire from the ground up. Please, please, PLEASE don't ever let this game lose support for more modern Operating Systems. The world would be a sadder place without Civilization III.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I have been offline and away from most gaming for a few years with work and all, but recently, I carved out some time to get back in the game.  I am starting with some of my old favorites, so Civ 3 was an easy choice. The turn-based strategy games takes lots of consideration and moves at manageable pace (think family or work needs something right now, so you can temporarily stop or save and come back in an hour or the next day.  The AIs are good enough to be present unpredictable challenges and opportunities.  A great game to make you think about all the things that make a winning strategy or a sorrowful second place.

It is a great break from a FPS (first person shooter) game, or is it the FPS is a good break from the strategic thinker game?

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I've played this game on and off for years, ever since the 'Gold Edition' launched in 2003.

It's easy to pick up, and absorbs your time as you race to expand your civilisation through a combination of growth and military conquest. Various civilisations provide different bonuses which cater to different play styles and strategies. For example, you can gain military bonuses to build large armies, scientific bonuses to facilitate technological advantages, commerce bonuses to offset whatever costs you decide to incur, as well as others.

You can customise the game such as map size and type, AI difficulty, types of victories and accelerated production for a quicker game. Note that large maps often end up taking a lot of time and turns become longer and longer as you manage large numbers of cities and units. Also on harder difficulties, rather than implementing optimum strategies, the AI receives bonuses and becomes ridiculously hard.

If you get bored of the standard random maps, you can load various scenarios that come with the game. There is even a quite comprehensive map editor which allows for custom maps and rules. You can create your own custom resources, units, techs, governments and civilisations. It's even possible with just the map editor to build cities on water.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#267 out of 612)... it's time for Sid Meier's Civilization III.

Arguably the most important, if not the best, entry in the venerable Civilization series. While today Civilization 5 may be the definitive version of Civilization, Civilization III used to claim that spot, and is still very much worth revisiting today--especially if you're looking to play Civ on an older PC that might groan and creak under the strain of modern games.

Civilization III is incredibly polished and boasts an enormous amount of content, especially with regard to mods. The 2D visuals still look gorgeous today and a modern CPU can bruteforce its way through that usual murderer of Civilization playthroughs, the late-game slog. Be warned, however, that Civilization III is a very old game, and it shows its age. Mostly this manifests in the UI, which is considerably less intuitive and clear than we're accustomed to these days--and, perhaps most problematically for new players, there aren't any tooltips. If you've never played a Civilization game before, you're in for a steep learning curve. And if it's been a while since you've played Civilization III and you're looking to revisit an old favorite, well, unless your memory is much greater than mine, odds are you'll have a fair bit of a learning curve to muddle through as well. Who'd've thought the most important innovation in the 4x genre over the last 20 years would be something as simple as tooltips?

Well, anyway. It's Civilization III: one of the finest turn-based strategy games ever produced. In many respects it falls short of its successors, most notably the wildly imaginative expansions of Civilization IV and the perfectly polished systems and mechanics of Civilization V, but it remains an excellent title nonetheless.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: If you want a simpler version of Civ, I can't recommend CIV III enough. It is quicker to learn, and much easier to pickup than modern civilization games. Perfect for beginners, and as you can see, I go back all the time when I need a break from other strategy games. The AI isn't too timid and there are trading options that make some of the other Civ games seem lacking. The trading system's simplicity is a big draw, and the lack of other peripherals such as religion and city states allow you to focus on building up your cities and armies.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I failed to take heed of other commenters who warned about the incompatibility issues. I regret making the mistake of purchasing and installing this game, believing that I would not suffer the same problems. Not the case. The game, in its current condition, is severely bugged (but it is also specified in "System Requirements" section of Steam that the game is compatible with Win2000/XP only).

Second problem: The game's AI settings apparently have been changed greatly since when I was playing the basic version of it from a CD, many years ago. I distincly remember how the difficulty would scale in a reasonable manner as you went up in difficulty settings. Not anymore. Probably due to the influence of the modding community, which I suspect would be hardcore gamers, even at the easiest settings the AI is completely focused on spamming cities and units, without a thought for developing their cities. I remember playing around the hardest difficulty settings before. In this version, even at the easiest settings any other civilizations you play against gang up on you from the get go.

I was still greatly pleased with reading the many civilopedia entries and visiting the nice memories of the old appearance of the game. However, I believe it is a broken piece of software now. And considering that it is almost an ancient game today, and that it has had 3 more sequels so far, I don't think any improvements will take place.

I do not recommend this game in its current condition.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: For about $1.30 you can't go wrong. The game is fun, addicting, but also can be very frustrating. The small map on the easiest difficulty is very easy which is fine especially for someone learning. However the same easiest difficulty on the largest maps are not even fun. They enemy AI is garbage. They team up against you and there is no way to keep up. If you make more troops it just costs more to support them all and you still get out numbered. I want to play a big game with 16 countries but I can't because of this. The game also crashes a lot. Another thing I don't like is the enemy is always mad if you walk on their territory. However it's okay for them to walk on your territory. Then when you complain to them too much they declare war. Small map it's not so bad because you can keep up with defending. Large map the other civs team up and it is not fun. I don't really enjoy to the small map. Game had so much more potential. Especially being a remake.Good thing for multiplayer.

review: This is a great quarantine game!  Steam breathed new life into it with updated internet play since the old gamespy internet play was gone.  So you can grind your friends' civilizations into the dirt for hours of fun :-)  Watch out when some of them claim they're just going past to look somewhere else- they may be gathering for a sneak attack without honorably declaring war first!  Plus truly anyone can play, probably ANY Windows machine alive today can run this old game and with the price dirt cheap no one can whine that it's too expensive.  Google for the "KeepRes" ini setting for better screen resolution.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: This game can be finicky in the intro and end cut scenes (sometimes freezing the game up from continuing), but the game allows for some intricate victory conditions, and even map setup, to give your chosen civilization either an edge or a challenge. With a gamut of nations, from Rome to Japan, to play as, each with their own unique units and traits, there is never a shortage of replayability and fun. This, and Alpha Centuari, are good choices for those who want to dip their toe into the TBS genre from the genius of Sid Meier without having to spend a lot of money. Overall, this is TBS at its finest.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: Civ 3 was the breakthrough for this classic turn-based strategy franchise. It's just detailed enough as to be intuitive, while not getting overly complicated as the later games in the series. Easy to pick up; hard to put down. Civ 3 was a childhood favorite that occupied hours at a time, and picking it up again after 10+ years is a real treat. It takes small storage and downloads in minutes (hooray for old games!). The graphics and AI are poor, but the nostalgia stands strong. As long as you can bear with the occasional crashes (it maybe didn't age so well? save often!), you'll get a great experience with a most excellent game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
There really should be a neutral option for whether or not you recommend a game, this one is ok, and if it's on sale then maybe you should get it.
It can be fun building cities and expanding to build a vast empire, but the strategic turn based combat is seriously broken.
The game has 8 difficulty levels and on the easiest it's too easy, but if you're one notch above the lowest setting you're REGULARLY going to lose a lot of fights that you really shouldn't be losing, and by that I mean you'll have veteran 3/2 units losing to regular 1/1 and 1/2 units, it completely kills the fun factor of the game for me when my superior units keep losing to inferior ones.

I like that you can stack combat units (not a feature in Civ 5) which felt more realistic than battles spread across a dozen tiles, but the stacks are easier to manage than the 'stack of doom' mechanic present in Civ 4. Very fun.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This is a fantastic strategy game against "fair" AI player, until one of the civilizations suddenly acquires "cheat" level power and wealth. All countries were similar within reason. I just quit after a long "building process". One of the opposing countries suddenly advanced to high level mechanics. My horse cavalry was being attacked by aircraft, automatic weapons, and tanks. No fun. Very disappointing. Happens every time. Too bad, otherwise a great game with simple, responsive graphics. Later versions have "silly", cartoon-like  graphics and are not as responsive.

Tried once again. After advancing into the industrial age, my AI opponents suddenly gained huge advances. Once again, found my horse cavalry defending against mechanized armored units and aircraft. When I viewed their technology, a few rounds earlier, we were almost even in terms of advancement. Very frustrating to work so hard, only to have the AI civs cheat! May try the cartoon style later versions, but they are not as nimble as the older version.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: consume

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
The game is very clunky and the 'tutorial' mode offers no help with most of the issues. The biggest problem i had were with an apparent unbalanced scaling in how the AI nations behave, even in the easiest mode. THey expand continuously with apparently no concern for territory or money. This further creates a problem when they settle cities between yours and comlain every time your troops move through the region as they HAVE TO DO to go anywhere. 
Another issue is lack of clarity in how to or ability to deal with internal issues such as civil disorder. The corruption mehanic doent mke a lot of sense and there doesnt see to be anything the player can do to minimize it except literally build all your cities directly around your capitol, which while strategically may be ideal, seriously limits expansion prospects. Building roads is a suggested mitigation move, but it doesn't appear to actually do anything. it's also apparently impossible to actually maintain or affect where the money in your cities goes.

My favourite version.   The only one that tops this - Alpha Centauri.   A game lost to time.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: Greatest game ever.  Only 2 real issues that I have ever had problems with.  #1  Automated exploring is idiotic.  If you send two units out they always end up in the same area or retrace their steps for 10 turns to make it back to one overlooked square they missed earlier instead of continuing into unexplored areas.  #2  Sometimes battles against vastly inferior opponents ends up with them winning.  E.G.  4 units with attacks of 4 go against 3 units with defenses of 2.  The attackers are wiped out.  This consistently happens in Civ, where a vastly superior unit is defeated by a vastly inferior unit.  I just sing a diddy, "the impossible last stand, the spearman defends his land, against waves of swordsmen, it's the impossible last stand."  That's how often it happens, I made up a silly song.  Other than that, I've never played a game more in my life.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: Amazing Game! Best instillation in the franchise if you ask me! A fun RTS with many factions to pick from (I believe it's 31 to be exact)! Enjoying making my own maps and playing them. Accessing the editor is a little difficult at first because you don't open it through steam, but your file browser instead (There's forums for this if you're interested)! The game is built upon many aspects which gives it a unique play-stile where you get to manage your Economy, Culture, Military, Diplomacy, Science/Technological advancements throughout the Bronze age, Midieval era, the Middle ages, The industrial era, the Modern era and beyond! Definately a 5/5 for me! And it certainly takes it's place among my top 10 game franchises along with The total war series, Halo, Call of Duty, Fortnite, Tomb Raider, Uncharted, Resistance, Men of War, Command and Conquer, and Star wars Battlefront! Definitely worth the money! Enjoy folks! Oh, and also, the difficulty varies significantly with the eight or so different levels, so for those of you who love a challenge, this game's for you! For those who want to easily walk all over their opressors, this game's for you! And for all of those who love their games so hard that all they ever do is get their butt's whooped, This games for you!

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I wish I could recommend this game, but it has changed so much. I played the "normal" edition (less playable civilizations, simpler mechanics, etc) of Civ 3 for 100s of hours as a kid. This game was a big part of my childhood. But, I do believe there must have been some digression and tweaking done for the "complete" version. 

The game seems very unbalanced, there are some bugs when talking to other civilizations (Windows 10), and it was just genuinely harder than it used to be even on the easiest settings. The combat mechanics bring a lot of unbalanced struggle to the game, unfortunately. It is frustrating to lose a majority of your army to one or two enemy units. It didn't used to be like that.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: This is still my favourite iteration of the Civilization franchise. It may not be as deep or flashy, but it has the aesthetics and epic atmosphere that I expect from a game of Civ. This Complete edition offers the most broad and fine-tuned edition of the game yet, and all passionate Civ fans owe it to themselves to give it a try.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: What makes CIV3 stand the test of time? Combat. The only Civ that can compare to 3 in terms of combat is Civ4. Every Civ after 4 wants you to play with a handful of cities and no army. Civ 3 is literally about taking over the world. Even 4 reigned this in because in 4 you need seige units to take cities. The unit sound effects in Civ4 don't sound like battle hardened badasses like they do in 3. After over 12 years of gaming I've spent more time playing this game than any other game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: This is NOT the Civ III that you used to play. The "complete" version turned the game even on the easiest setting into an impossible mess. As soon as any AI meets you, they instantly hate you and turn on you, regardless of the settings. No such thing as "friendly" or "polite". It's just "OH! It's YOU!!! Prepare to die!!!". You can have units that are 3 generations ahead of another player, and it will take 3 of them to make even a dent in 1 of theirs. 1 of their warriors will take out several of your medieval infantry without a problem. Not to mention they can build whatever they want regardless of resources, and they don't have to fund or pay for units, so 1 city can create dozens of units every couple of turns. No matter how good you are, you can't withstand a swarm of several dozen units that are overpowered, and have the strength of industrial era weapons, attacking your cities each and every turn from the very beginning. And that's on the easiest settings!!! So go find a disc version that's not this Complete one. The "Complete" means "Complete Garbage".

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Timeless and perfect.

Much different from the newer Civs in my opinion. Civ 3 feels like an epic board game: ridiculous numbers of units (on the same tile!) and sprawling empires with dozens of cities. A great option for micro-managers, but you don't have to make it complicated to have fun. The soundtrack is phenomenal.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
...Well, on a sale of 1 to 10 in difficulty, I place it roundabouts a 8.5, because, and I actually have played longer on another account, in the 3 years I've been attempting to beat "Easy" mode, I have done so exactly 0 times. Maybe Im a terrible player, but, warning issued. Prepare to be stymied.
 One complaint I might have is the balancing mechanics between AI and the Player. Unless you go aggressive expansionist, or seclude yourself from the rest of the AI, you will be dominated swiftly. Is there really any chance of success if you spawn next to an AI? No. They will get out 12 Archers before you can build One measly Warrior.
 Otherwise, it's a great game, but If you'd want more winnability, try out CIV5. If you're a "do or die" Masochist who wants to prove their strategic genius, may the odds be ever in your Favor. This is the game for you.

review: I never outgrew Civilization 3. It was one of my first games right after Warcraft 2 and the old school C&Q. I love the turn base of civ 3 and really enjoyed the game for years and year. I am only now realizing there is another layer to this game with mods and multiplayer scenarios and I'm excited to get into that now. Would recommend this game to anybody of any age.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: Civ III is simple, some of the game mechanics are broken, but for a 2001 grand strategy game, this is right up there with the best. Some incredible mods go a long way -- Worldwide (for general gameplay balance) and MEM II (for an amazing Crusader Kings style game) are my favorites. I've probably logged well over 1,000 hours back when I owned the disk version. Love it quite a bit.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: An excellent turn-based city building game that is nearly always fun, outside of standard maps such as Earth there is a random seed. Be warned though there are some issues with some of the cinematics that can lock up the game. Personally I have had issue with the space-race victory and need to skip the victory summaries or risk the game freezing, there may be some fixes just haven't spent the time to check. Also there is an excellent selection of mods for the game ranging from textures to maps and scenarios although they must be sought out on  other sites. Now if only there was Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri on Steam always wanted to play it atleast once.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: This game has saved me 15/25/55 dollars, as I have no desire to purchase a newer civ game since playing this. I played for years as a kid on CD, so the 100 hours I have is more like 1000. The one knock on this game is that its very easy to snowball and very hard to come back from losing a war, even if you get out of it quickly, so unless you have the patience to build the units and take all the cities required for domination, the game sort of loses its fun at about 1700AD give or take. This game has provided me with hours upon hours of boredom prevention and excitement since I was about 7 years old and my uncle gave me and my brother this game on CD. Definitely recommend.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I used to love playing this on my old DELL tower PC back when I was a little tyke. But now, I'm afraid it has not aged well when used with newer tech. The UI is very buggy on newer displays, and even has a habit of changing the resolution on Windows 10. I bought this on sale for about 76 cents, so I can't really complain too much. Brought back some good memories.

I did find a fix for this eventually, so it does run a bit smoother now. 
I absolutely love this game, but please understand the risks involved in playing a 18 year old game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: The AI has ridiculous advantages past Regent difficulty, and the natural hostility to the player gets old faster than in Civ II MGE. The combat system is poorly designed, the terrain modifiers are imbalanced, and maybe half of the world Wonders are worth building. After playing through twice on Monarch difficulty, I will never play this game again.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This game is a classic, you are either here to play the game that got you into the series (like me). Or you play the newer titles and hear people refer to the old games and you want to find out for yourself what got so many people hooked on Civilization.  For either purpose I can fully recommend picking this game up. 

For a old game it is pretty stable for new systems and have even played multiplayer for the first time ever with this Steam version and it worked flawlessly. So at least for me with Windows 10 and a modified HP Pavilion from 2014 it works fine.

For some reason I think the graphics are a little better on this version then I remember from the disc version and this is a more complete edition so it has more Civs. But for those coming from Civ 5 or 6 and never played this game just beware that you are getting the old predecessor of your beloved title.

In terms of gameplay I enjoy this version the most out of all the Civilization titles. It's simple but doesn't lack depth at all. I feel like it holds your hand a little less and seems slower paced. However that may be because in 5 and 6 you have religion that you may want to rush to make and it feels less on rails as in 5 and 6 you pick Civ traits such as tradition, liberty, etc. Not to say those are bad but just different.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
"Mummy, please, just one more turn..."

STRICT ALERT!!! The game is going to cause dependency/addiction to it.

Only play if you have many hours to spend on it - don't even start if you have less than two hours of free time!

Shame it still lacks HD resolution support, just like it doesn't have actually ANY graphics settings - although when it got released in 2001 it didn't look bad compared to its age being an isometric 2D-game. Still, some lags/AI thinking times might occur, which I cannot say agreeable looking at its graphics level...

I think this entire game should get an HD remaster - newer than Windows XP operating systems can have serious compatibility support issues with the game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Jak uvařit svíčkovou.
Ingredience
cibule
sůl
3  lžíce hladká mouka
3  lžíce rostlinný olej
50  g slanina
900  g hovězí svíčková odblaněná
3  dl smetana hustá
bobkový list
4  ks nové koření
citronová šťáva
3  dl vývar
4  ks pepř celý zrnka
300  g kořenová zelenina
brusinkový kompot nebo rybízový džem
cukr

Svíčkovou osolíme, protkneme 2/3 slaniny nakrájené na klínky a na tuku zprudka po všech stranách opečeme. Maso za chvíli vyjmeme, přidáme zbytek na kostičky nakrájené slaniny, očištěnou na plátky nakrájenou zeleninu, cibuli a osmahneme do světlehněda.

Pak znovu vložíme maso, přidáme koření, mírně podlijeme a dusíme v troubě. Maso poléváme šťávou a podle potřeby podléváme vývarem. Měkké maso vyjmeme, šťávu vydusíme na tuk, zaprášíme moukou, osmahneme a postupně ředíme zbytkem vývaru a smetanou.

Omáčku dochutíme cukrem, citronovou šťávou nebo octem a dobře povaříme. Potom omáčku prolisujeme přes cedník. Nalijeme ji na maso a ještě na plotně prohřejeme. Maso nakrájíme na plátky. Podáváme s knedlíky a brusinkami nebo rybízovým džemem.

Oh and it scales to modern resolutions quite well too.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Don't be fooled by the number above, I have more than 3k hours played at least. On the the review now:

I've been playing on and off since it's release. I've learned a lot of history and English terminology through playing this game as a kid. The game play is not the best: the next games are superior game play wise. However they eliminated the endless combat that reigns over Civ 3. It is one of these games, uniquely so, that you can hoard military units, stack them up near the enemy's borders, declare war and take 5 cities, big or small, before the enemy gets his turn. Although a lot, A LOT, of micromanagement is required to pull off this kind of tactic, it is really rewarding if somewhat tedious. The technology system is fine, it's slower than later games, but you have more time to play between eras. Most unique units are well-designed. A lot of Wonders are broken (Statue of Zeus, cough cough) and can allow you to cut through early eras like a knife through butter. Early eliminations are common and wonder fights are exciting. 

The OST is BONKERS. I still listen to it, so many years later, even without playing. Jungle sounds, mesoamerican music etc. Really well orchestrated.

Overall, I've been enjoying this game for so many years. It's my childhood darling so I may be a bit far from objectively measuring its pros and cons.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: By far the best in the series, Civ III has all the complexity of the previous civ games while adding many new UI features that really make the game shine. This is the game out of all of them that takes up the most of my time. If you're debating over civ IV vs civ V, they're both nothing compared to this. Provided you like complexity, which is my beef with civs 4 and 5... they dumbed them down too much. This is civilization at its best.

Later civs really try hard to develop things like diplomacy, religion, social policies etc. but I'm out for global domination which is very possible in this game unlike later ones where they make it much more difficult and I'd say they actively discourage it. The later ones feel almost like accounting games with all the things you have to consider but this one is simple enough and straightforward. Old game but always a blast to make stacks of death and mow down every civilization you find. When on sale you can get it for about a dollar. I'll take being able to play this over a mcchicken any day.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I played this for untold hours off my CD, likely from the base, or close to the base version (note, 
 I bought this as a backup copy, what does that tell you?).  I couldn't recommend it enough back in the day, but it's a bit older, and thus the graphics aren't as high.  The later editions added things like vassal states, which you can turn off, but I never liked, and I like to play with all rules on.  This older version has all the main features, and later editions try more and more to make complete conquest of the map harder and harder so players don't get frustrated by being knocked out in multiplayer, but it takes away from the global domination that most old players aim for.  So, in that case, older is better!

****NOTE:on Windows 10, always hit space bar when it starts up to skip the login screen, or an error will make it crash when the "2K" animation ends.  This is a super old game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I will start this review in two seperate forms, one for interested newcomers and then the Old Guard.

I will list off the pros first before the cons of this game, Civilization 3 is a different twist of the game than you may be familar with 4 and 5. Go in understanding this switch:
     -Its an old game, if you can run the actual game, there should be no real issues.
     -Graphically, it's a sound experience and not many real issues, the modding community can find you bug fixes or new skins. Its pleasing regardless and you won't really be let down by this game.
     -Combat is similar to Civ 4, simple dice combat where units have health bars going between 3-6, strength and defense stats play their parts and very simple to understand. There are Offensive Units, Defensive Units and Manovuer units, no exceptions and combat is based on these theorectical roles.
     -31 Civs that each have 1 unique unit, unless mods are involved. Civ bonuses are general in that they have two traits which give them bonuses which are shared by others, Militaristic, Religious, Industrists, etc.
     -Diplomacy is sound and reliable, techs can be traded directly as well as maps, I will list faults soon
     -Happiness is based per city, with simple factors involved including conscription
     -Civfanatics Community and its modding community are lovely and its still alive and well, just no Workshop

The Cons:
     -Civ 5 has a prediction based combat, units do no die with one attack on even matches. Not the case for this game, they fight till they die unless they are manovuer units against inf. Bullshit can and will happen, don't cry.
     -The AI Diplomacy is very defensive and almost always cautious, wary or spiteful towards you, no exceptions.
     -Its really easy to find yourself fighting half the world because of one war, tech trading is enabled so you can find yourself backwater as they maintain amiable relations and trade those tech with one another while they fight you. 
     -Multiplayer is old, the members are not exactly nub-friendly, I myself was 3 years old when this game came out.
     -Game doesn't work for you, you're fucked, not much anyone can do for you.
     -In my opinion, the hardest Civilization I have every played, it will humble you many times over.
In the end it is a Civ-game, you can't really go wrong with trying. It is the game that personally got me into Civilization and its unique-ness will likely find you some memorable gameplay. Hey and if you get the game and love it, I'd always be willing to play with you by e-mail or I might even try GameRanger. Good luck on your adventure To Stand The Test of Time

Returning Civ 3, should you get it on steam? Yes and no, while digital copies are nice, its not any different from the disk. That being said, I prefer it on Steam. I have purchased this game three times, one the authentic Civ III Gold Version, which was outstanding and I loved it. However, eventually I got a new computer and it turns out the disc was ruined. I got the game a third time over E-bay, the only source I could find which remains, this time the Complete. Features were missing and I couldn't even access them no matter what I tried, the conquest files corrupted and Play the World missing. I got a new computer, my current, running Windows 8.1, 4GB RAM and Integrated Graphics. The disc would not load the game, but viola, I found the steam version was the cheapest to begin with. Its the same game as you know, and for me everything was working well. Underneath I will discuss the major steam issues:
     -For me at least, Steam Overlay does not appear to work and I wouldn't know how to fix it, it could be a personal issue, I don't know. 
     -There are serious issues people have with getting this dinosaur game to work on new computers. Win 7 tends to have more compatiability issues with the game than Win 8(.1). Your at risk here, but this is usually the cheapest alternative
     -Modding is simple but remember, access the files through the properties tab by right-click the game in the Library Tab
     -Multiplayer is not run by Steam servers, nor GameSpy Arcade, it shut down if you haven't followed the game. It is now accessible over GameRanger. I do not know how that works or even attempted to access multiplayer.

This game would be perfect but for a few really aggravating glitches that ultimately let it down.

I have played this game for years and it still astonishes me now how much the AI will F you up the anal passage if you have got ahead of it, what it will do is the AI will mysteriously get a wonder that they should no shape or form have.  That is one thing that is a massive aggravation.

Then there is the AI has the ability to build mass amounts of settlers, military gear, etc, etc from the start.  Now I am good at this game, played for years and I still can not get archers and defensive units in numbers after a few rounds.  Basically the AI cheats, anyone who says AI and machines do not cheat, hang yourself now before I hang you and it is ultimately this games let down, its only let down is the AI will F you over.  Sure you deal with it, but it is the way the AI goes about it.  It is not subtle in the slightest and as far as I am concerned further proof that computers cheat and have been thinking for themselves for quite sometime.

Because of the massive aggravating glitch F's this game has, it only gets a 6/10.  Sort the glitches out and this is a 10/10 game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: Coming from Civ V as my first Civ game - well, technically it was Civ Revolution but let's pretend that didn't happen -, I found this game enjoyable. In my limited experience so far though, there seems to be less things to do, however the present mechanics are on a larger scale. For example, there are no social policies but a few government types, religion only in the form of a few religious buildings I guess but nothing customizable and so on. Though on the other hand, you build far more cities and mass produce units, often the same things over and over. It's the same things with workers, for the most part you build roads and either irrigation or mines on the tiles. Overall, the core experience looks like it's the enjoyable same, but a simpler zen-like experience. I could also run the game on both Windows 7 and Windows 10 both x64 just fine, resolution is also ok.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Interested in buying this game? Here are some facts:

Pros:
> Relatively simple to play (much easier and much less stuff on your screen than the more expensive Civ IV and Civ V)
> In-depth historical information about each tribe, unit, civilization technology, everything!
> Very good and realistic diplomancy, tech tree, and battle system.
> Lots of different options to choose. You can take over the world, launch a spacecraft into space, become the cultural centre of the world, and more!
> Loads of civilizations to choose from, from the Persians to the Zulus to the Americans and more.
> If you're bored of the normal start-from-scratch games, you can try a Conquest, sending you to a small point in time such as the Rise of Rome, Age of Discovery, Napoleonic Europe, and more. You can also play one of the hundreds of scenarios!
> Multiplayer lets you play with all your friends! Play over the internet or have a hot seat at parties!
> Turn-based strategy, so you can take as long as you want. There's no having bad hardware, everyone has a level playing field for this game.
> Only $5, or even cheaper on a sale! Not many games as good as this one can be bought this cheap nowdays.

Cons:
> Windows 10 users may need to set themselves up.
> If it means anything to you, "Just one more turn!"

In conclusion: A great, turn-based strategy game based on leading your civilization through the test of time. Not expensive and worth multiple times its cost. Buy it!

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
civ3 creates an impression that is it much more designed for robots than humans

it seems as well AI acts with perfect knowledge of map (which is nearly the only strong way to heavily cheat on this without some quadruple bonuses to everything, however all those are a thing on top difficulty i bet; and in those old civs you pretty sure are not winning in this absurd case)

it seems AI doesn't really try to unite against you in case of lead (though maybe does get furious at riches), yet is overly happy to try silly backstabs / 'surprise attacks' or else; it may even try to assault clearly later era stronghold with simple hordes that would almost never win there

oh and there's the quite massive downside in old civ - combat is literally random, so much that it matters almost endlessly, since there are massive terrain bonuses as well and ancient spearmen could very well beat tanks; it's not even a weird and rare case - hopelessly outdated AI hordes may just jump onto your mountains anytime and become unmovable force

there is a lot of inconvenience with units such as limits to upgrading, mostly no true way to skip tons of unit movements and such (maybe in case of railroads it becomes sort of that), while there are tons of units and often clumsy or limited control over them - and then 'same continent' is breaking minds of automated workers, there was a case where they literally rushed through many foreign borders and large lands that are hostile - to sometimes work on nearly or actually foreign volcano that recently exploded - and then instantly all die to yet another explosion, while they stand right on top of volcano

AIs for some reason barely ever wish to cooperate anyhow equally, even if it's them who often try to ally their weak nation to much more advanced one - even if it's exactly they who backstabbed you and awfully need protection now - of course it's you who always should pay army's worth of upkeep in protection treaty; then there's both positive and strange moment - bots can be (furious) at you yet still seriously try to ally and get protection

civ3 is somehow quite confusing and unintuitive i suppose, even when simultaneously tools available + core mechanics are ridiculously simple (but even pacing is very strange); it also seems to take massive time to playthrough even a bit - and without much management i guess (spammy) AI and all those older type mechanics can result in a quick death of civilization

it did have some nice ideas but the rest can simply create rather stupid spammy - defensive-favoring (and as well ruining that for YOU the player, because you lack any extra automation possible) grind, starting even from most ancient times where first of all units can be massed and rushed by population that generally anyone has and some do in massive surplus

overall civ3 has either too serious or too numerous problems to be offset by a few good moments; i'd say in practice it is easily nearly unplayable, inconvenient and quite mindless - while serious business going on against you won't let you be mindless one (or there you could lose on the easiest setting possible); it is possibly not even really challenging since maps feature very inhospitable lands (full of mountains not to even settle or ever grow anything) while as well rich and useful plains

so from the start it seems about all factors are against you; that's somewhat interesting but not for long (and that's a bit too much patience still)

since it is often not even easy to survive - some a bit casual or even a much later civ5 player will likely be plainly outspammed by ruthless AI if they miss about anything in proper setup and management (and when unfamiliar, there must be a lot to miss)

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete

Sid Meier's Civilization III is the de-facto greatest game in terms of basic graphics and gameplay-wise, especially in the entire Sid Meier's Civilization series. It brung more things the other two didn't implement, such as animated leaders, advisors, and updated isometric view, and brand new land graphics simulating the real world, and even coastlines.

This version, however, is the greatest buy I have ever accomplished. You got editors, and other civilizations bundled with this! It has all three expansions, and adds a functioning multiplayer! I love this game and it even competes with my love for Civilization IV. I just love it, and you guys should get it at any opportunity, such as sales and special events.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This game is a good starting point for newcomers to the Civilization series and currently the best value for money. It is fully compatible with modern systems and still worth playing today. The visual aesthetic of the game is one of its best features, and I still consider III to be the best looking Civilization game, due to its appealing artstyle and readability.

Civ III lacks some of the sophisticated gameplay mechanics introduced in the later games and I consider the combat in particular to be a weaker point of this game, as it usually amounts to just mindlessly building more units than your opponents. Despite this, Civ III gets the job done simply and effectively, which is why I always come back to it over the other games in the series. The Conquests scenarios are an interesting addition to the game and I have replayed them countless times. There are also numerous custom scenarios and mods available. If you have an interest in history and like strategy games, I would fully recommend Civilization III.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: I absolutely hate this game. I've played Call to Power 1 and 2, Sid Meier's Civ 5, 6, and this. I see all these reviews about how this is still the best Civ game, and I just do not see what they're seeing. In Civ 5 and 6, the enemy AI will at least kill and absorb far weaker AI. They will at least every once in awhile do little pretend wars where they attack another equal AI's city (not take it, but just damage it ). The enemy AI in this game will always be permanently allied against you, even if you pick for them to be the least aggressive they can be (useless option). The combat is the most frustrating, rng-based, tedious, time-consuming, micro-managing ****fest I've ever seen. You can have many units occupy a tile, but they can only attack 1 at a time. You would think that means combat would at least be better than Civ 5 and 6, but like I said, the rng is so stupid that you have to make sure you have an advantage of 5x or more, unless you want to just load half the time and try the battle again, cuz you will fail half the time at a 2x advantage. And what I mean by that is this - You can have a unit with twice as much attack as they have defense, they can be wounded, sitting in a grassland/plain, not fortified, not across a river, and there's still a good chance you will lose if you attack him. In addition to that, you can NOT fully kill an enemy by bombarding. This means that you have to rely on rng attacking to actually kill any enemy military unit. Call to Power 2 sucks because you can't set up a scenario where the AI put up any threat (they won't attack you with anything more than a few units ever), and this game sucks for the opposite reason, because the AI only wants you dead and they have huge advantages even on low difficulties. It especially doesn't help that the maps spawn such few horses and iron (even though you NEED them to get anything past starting units in this game), seems to always put them near the AI and far away from you, and punishes you greatly if you build a town far away from your own (through waste/corruption penalties), in which, you would need to connect that town with a road in order to build those horse/iron units in your other towns. If you don't connect that town to your civilization, then like I said, the waste/corruption is so bad that you won't get to build ANYTHING in that town. The enemy AI also destroys your lonely roads in no time. I'm uninstalling this game and never considering it again. BLIZZARD, PLEASE PUT CALL TO POWER 1 UP FOR DIGITAL DOWNLOAD, SO I CAN ACTUALLY HAVE FUN AGAINST AI AGAIN!

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: So, yeah, the graphics aren't what we're used to now, but this is still a great game.  Far and away better than the one that comes next, Civ IV.  FAR better.  Enjoyable, not easy to win -- I lost my first two games...mostly because there's no tutorial that I could find and the buttons are not exactly intuitive.  Heck, the game I won I didn't do all that well on.  Still, fun.  It's certainly not 5, but it's a nice change if you like old-school games.  Well worth the incredible low price.  Plays like a champ for me, no glitches at all.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This is The Best version of "Civilization" in series. The new "comic look" they started in Civ4 gives me eye cancer. So lame look since Civ4, which probably appeals only to 4-8 year kids. This is why I stick with The Perfect Civ3.

P.S.

Runs perfectly on Linux (Ubuntu 16.04 with 2560 x 1440 resolution monitor).

P.P.S.

To run in Linux:

a)
On a steam client go to "Steam > Settings > Steam Play" and check option "Enable Steam Play for all titles".

b)
Run a game first time - it probably won't start if You have large resolution monitor like me, but thats alright - the first run will create a conquests.ini (~/.steam/steam/steamapps/common/Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete/Conquests/conquests.ini) file.

Put these lines in that file:

KeepRes=1
PlayIntro=0

Save changes and play now till you drop dead.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This game is actually pretty good and a nice way to pass the time, but I don't understand why you can't have infinite turns to have that alternate earth timeline atmosphere that it takes place in your own version of Earth where your Civilisation can further go through its ups and downs with no sight of any kind of game victory in any horizon, but instead the best we can get is 1000 turns, which in my opinion is pretty displeasing since I was able to get a cultural victory with 1000 turns in just one go, on a small island surrounded by sea, in a very large map. I don't know if you CAN continue to run your civilization after a victory, because the 2 times I did get an endgame and went to click "OK", my game immediately freezes and stops working, making me have to quit the game.
Overall, it's a very fun game for you to pass the time, but it's going to be a quite the downer if you want to fully invest in your civilization for as long as you want (which would usually be "forever and ever" in some cases).
Overall, this game is a 8.5/10 in my opinion.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III is a turn-based strategy game on where you can play as one of many nations/countries and play on various maps which would be the "Earth" for that map. This complete edition concludes of the base game, Civilization III, Civilization III Play the World & Civilization III Conquest. We have many scenarios in this game with examples of them being Rise of Rome, World War 2 Pacific and even Earth type maps which you can either have true starting locations as your desired nation or have the spawn randomized. 

PROS
- CIv 3 has the biggest maps out of any other Civ game.
- We have no limitations on units like we had on every sequel. Units can stack which gave a much more war feeling to the game.
- If you want a game to last at least a week or even a month. On this game you can make it happen.
- For an old game it still runs smoothly.
- Multiplayer still works, so you can play with friends and/or family.
- Gameplay is simple, but you can make mistakes easily and the enemy will take advantage of that 

CONS
- Dated graphics (can be a + or a -)

Overall
This is and always will be my favourite civ 3 game, the sequels are all about fancy graphics and less war. If you want to actually feel like you have a civilization then this is the game for you. If you want the ultimate experience, on an earth map and the biggest map you can dream of. Then pick this map. TETurkhan Test of Time. This comes with various game types that include of spawning with pre-made cities like earth is today with the available civilizations in the game, true location start which allows you to where your country's first capital was. Or have it randomized. So you could have England in India or the Japanese in Africa. This is the biggest map the game has to offer and with the size of it. You are talking at least a couple of weeks to finish, if you plan to go with a total domination game. Well I'ma say it'll take you a little over a month.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Long story short: I bought Civilization 6, it bored me, I went back to previous versions till I found the Civ III CD. I forgot I had it, I forgot I used to play the game, the CD didn't install on Win 10, I went back to Steam and invested $1.49 on a download version... WOW I remember this game... that dick Alexander! The Cavalry, the awesome advisors, the incredible balance of resourses that keeps them relevant and even vital throughout the game. The expansion of territory and number of cities that increases your gold and power and access to more resources and luxuries instead then weight down your empire sustainability.  Best Civilization Ever!!!!

And if you are in for a change of pace... play Elimination.... build a small empire on a huge scale world and wait (with 6 or 7 offensive units) for the AI players to spam their cities near you and raze the newest most undefended one, rinse and repeat.
It never gets old.  :D

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: I've been coming back to this game year after year.  Civ IV, V, and VI have tended to streamline play and take on a more multiplayer-oriented mindset, which is great if that's what you want; but I keep coming back for Civ 3 for its month-long games, detail, and versatility.  I'll concede the vanilla game isn't the best (though the built-in scenarios are fun), but over the years I've edited the default scenario to a point that fits my playstyle: more resources types, greater differentiation in terrain, more divergent unit types, more engaging naval forces, and a modern era that holds a bit more interest.

Info: Windows 10 users will need to do a few tweaks to make this run correct & look as it should on a modern HD monitor, first find the configuration file conquests.ini, open with notepad, scroll to the bottom & add the line "keepRes=1" to run the game at your display resolution, next find the file civ3conquests.exe, right click & in properties select to run both as administrator and in windows XP SP3 compatibility to fix a bug where the game freezes at the end of a game.

You're welcome & enjoy this classic ^_^

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Hearing good things about this; I tried it for the first time in 2011. I enjoyed it initially; the learning curve was interesting and I wanted to know how good I could get at it. Some great features stood out, and I even played it with a friend on LAN.

But it being so dated, and lacking modern user-friendly polish that so many devlopment teams easily manage these days, it regretfully doesn't stand up to modern games for me. I'd spend ages in a match and only realise far into it that I was going to lose, and couldn't see the skill behind doing better next time.

I'd give this one a miss, unless you love RTS turn based games or lost your original disks, since it's cheap.

★★☆☆☆

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I think this is my favorite Cic game, I only  have a few hours played, but I had it before I got it on steam.  This was a huge improvement over Civ 2.  The ability to turn other factions cities in the middle if you empire thanks to culture was a much needed improvement.  Hex also made for smoother  movement, in addition managing where citizens worked in a city was supper easy, its also the last on to stop being that easy (not sure about Civ 4, i skiped that one).  For the most part units are the same as Civ 2, except now each civ has a unique unit, some more useful than others since some are only useful on the "BC eras" while other are far better in the "modern era" (a chariot vs F15).  Each civ also has bonuses to various stats, such as faster navel units or a science research bonus. The xpacs add some nice content, but to me they seem t make the game end faster, but that could just be from being engrossed in the game. 

Civ 5 and Beyond Earth are good (as  is Civ 6 Im sure), each has their own things that make it better, but in the end Civ 3 is at the top of my list, even if i dont play it as much as the other ones right now.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I've played Civ3, Civ4, Civ5, and Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri (also known as SMAC).  Civ3 and SMAC are still the best of these to me.  I wish Steam had the full version of SMAC, cuz I never was able to get the expansion pack for that one.

I got THIS version of Civ3 as part of a package deal.  I already had a CD-ROM of the original game and played that a lot.  I had plans to hunt down the expansion packs for it as well, but then Steam came into my life.

I compare playing Civ3 to a Poker tournament.  It's pretty easy to learn how to play, and hard to win in the long run.  Despite all the hours I've put into it, I've never won a game, even when I thought I was supposed to.  The point isn't to win, though; the point is to play.  Every time I've done that, I've learned something else.  I've also quit many games due to the fact that it was obvious I had been dealt a losing start.  Replay value approaches the infinite due to the sheer number of variables that go into a game, most of which are customizable, and some of which are procedurally generated (including the map, which will make or break you most times).

I was hoping that Civ4 and Civ5 would prove to be closer to this game and SMAC combined.  That turned out not to be the case.  Because of my love for this game and SMAC, I've found it difficult to enjoy 4 and 5 for what they offer.  They didn't feel like improvements on the formula, TBH.  I say that cuz, well, Civ3 is just that frickin' good.

For me, Civ3 is a fine, and also somewhat extreme, example of how gameplay is superior to graphics.  I can't say that pining for the days of sprites is in everyone's best interest; but sometimes, awesome polygonal renderings are just too much, or they wind up being more of a hindrance or distraction.  That said, Civ3 is not particulary known for its awesome sprites, either.  Still, you know what is what in this game.  Plenty of people made mods for the game as well.  I've seen Lord of the Rings mods, and one or two intended to improve how terrain features looked.  I never got into these, myself, although I do wish some things were easier to see due to design.

If you like strategy games, or are looking to try one, give Civ3 a shot, or let it be your introduction.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: My original experience with Civilization and without a doubt my favorite. First got the game from my parents back in 2004 and rebought it on Steam back in 2015. title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This game is a gem.. it delivers a unique atmosphere and enjoyment that no other civ managed to equal, not even civ 6. 

PROS
- Each era contains its unique soundtrack, and nore of them are as boring as the soundtracks of civ 5 and civ 6. 
- You want to conquer a city? Go for it, send in a ton of units and take it.. your offensive units vs your enemy's defensive units, no insane bonus for defending a city and no ridiculous penalties for capturing as many cities as you want (looking at you civ 5). 
- The fact that you can stack as many units as you want on a single stack was a vital mechanic that civ 5 should have never taken away.. it makes the game clunky and unnecessarily limitating.
- All units have 2 values, an offensive one and a defensive one, allowing for more complex strategies and making every units a lot more unique and specialized. 

CONS
The AI will be unforgiving and sooner or later, every single one of them will swarm you will armies aimed at ending you.. it can be very challenging for players who like to simply give up when things get difficult, because they will. They progress very quickly with science, just to make things even more difficult. For this reason, i strongly suggest new players to choose the easiest level of difficulty at first, or maybe the one after it for players who played a lot with other civs. 

CONCLUSION
Every mistakes that civ5's developpers made, the ones that we hoped were going to be fixed in civ 6.. well, this game will give you an experience of a vastly more satisfying and authentic civ game. after playing this game and enjoying it, you'll feel like civ5 took the wrong turn and civ6 will no longer be relevant to you.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This is a classic Civ game, but with a classic flaw. The game cheats and cheats hard. By cheating the games AI will settle cities miles away from their territory and right next to yours. Thus forcing you to fight to keep your land free. Then after a few dozen turns they will send in a few stacked armies that almost always will desimate your troops.

Now this cheat isn't impossible to beat, but the deadly troop stack will sooner or later spell doom for you and your civ. Only real way around this cheat is to get an island, stay isolated as long as possible, and then hold out.

In the end having to play the game in isolation is boring and results in this game being a dud.

It really makes everything feel so much better when you learn how to [strike]stop your financial adviser from bothering you because you've made your country bankrupt by pouring all the money into military[/strike] play by yourself, it's cathartic.

Pick up this game. Play this game. Waste time here.
Simple at first glance, but one of the most deep strategy games I've played.

Dart like loading speed and complex stratergy makes this game the best game I have every played and at ~£3 (marked down to ~75p at the time of this review) what is not to like. The graphics aren't even noticably early 2000's (I actually had to check that it was released in the early 2000's for this review). This game is as great now as it was when released. I'd give it 10/10 and 
[b]I nominated this game for the test of time award.[/b]
especialy the tukmans test of time mod.
:-)

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: Civ 3 is a great entry in the series, but there are some reasons why it doesn't hold up to the newer games. First is the combat and how the only viable defensive strategy is stacking all your units in your cities. The no military unit stacking rule starting in Civ V is such a simple and huge advancement. Second is how bad the AI is. The AI is just terrible compared the newer games. Third is that the quanitity of your cities is better than the quality. It is always the better option to settle as many cities as possible, even within your own borders. What keeps me coming back to this game is the nostalgia, the scenarios, and the simplicity. I love playing the WWII Pacific, New World, and Napoleonic Wars scenarios. For how cheap you can get this game there is no reason a Civ fan should not have this in their library.

However, when I tried to look for the settings file, it was not there. I had to spend 20 minutes trying to find out what file to change, but was unable to in the end. title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: I need to be careful not to play this game too often. When I do play, I get sucked in for hours on end; it's so addictive. I used to own the CD-ROM set years ago - a gift from my brother. Over time, the CDs got scratched, and I was wary when buying this game. I remembered the addictive effects it had on me in high school - staying up all hours of the night, every night. This time around, I can handle it better. If anyone out there is considering buying this game, just be careful - set yourself a timer based on the maximum limit you're willing to let yourself play in any given night. Otherwise, you'll keep playing until you crash, and you'll end up missing school, being late for work, and ignoring UFOs passing overhead.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Pros-
Graphics are Good. Even though it came out in 2001.
Comes with Alot of maps and can be randomly generated too. Example (UK Map, World Map)
There is mods out for the game here is the link - https://www.civfanatics.com/civ3/downloads/
The price of the game is $5 which is pretty good asking price. 
There is an Editor so that you can create your own map or scenerio.

-Mixed (Depends on perspective.)
The turns are pretty long for me at late game if I play on Huge Map. It would take 30 seconds to minute to go through in later stages of the game.

When you download the game you have to manualy set the resolution in the files to 1080p  which would only take a minute. You can find a tutorial online.

The game is less complex compared to CIV 4 or CIV 5. For example you can't edit the details of your goverment like you can in CIV 4 and there is no religion system like civ 4.

Con-
Not really anything I can pinpoint right now.


My Recomendation- You should get if you want a simple turn based strategy game. It's only $5 USD. Also when the game goes on sale it would go down to around 2.50 to 3 dollar range.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete

Recommend without hesitation, even to a player coming from V as their only Civ game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This is interesting. First, I must mention my first contact with Civilization was acquiring a copy of IV from Bookman's. Had to sell it back a time later, but since this Autumn (Black Friday) Sale showed up with this, IV, and V for cheap, I decided to acquire them all.

Having given this backstory, I must say that III is amusing, if a bit archaic, compared to my memories of IV (I'll get to replaying that soon). However, some of the visuals are beautiful, and the AI can be... interesting. Mostly, I miss Spock's narration, but that is a minor quibble.

All in all, it is an interesting intro to the series (since I don't know where one would find I or II).

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I have played a lot of Civ games, from Advanced Civilizations on DOS all the way up to the brand new Civ VI. And this is still my favorite of all of them. It is definitely not the prettiest or most user-friendly civ game, but its grit and punishing difficulty (at the higher settings) give it a realism lost in a lot of the newer Civ games.  That being said the game is a huge leap foward from a lot of its easier counterparts, though it's still not as difficult at Advanced Civilizations, you don't need to mount your C:/ Drive to play it and there is a manual... Stupid RNG no explanation Civil Wars...

Anyway, long story short:
If you are new to the Civilization Franchise I might recommend starting with  Civ V, its an easier more friendly game. That being said, if you are a veteran of the franchise or of the strategy genre, Civ III will give you a more difficult, more immersive, and more brutal experience, and is well worth the $1-$5 it costs.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I played them all but VI(reviews did that game in for me), this is the best of the series in my opinion. The flow and pace of the game is better than Civ V,Naval combat is wonderful and you actually have a good chunk of time to play with the old sailboats. Stratigic bombing can actually be a game changer,like many of the tech advancments. Unless you play it on the lowest dificalty setting the AI can keep up with you tech wise,to the point where they have guns around the time you have guns, they have nukes around the time you have nukes.
The games pace was really thought out, it works so much better then the rest of the Civ games for the most part .  Sure it has dated graphics, but it's a polished game with the best over all gameplay of the series. 

Also, I played this game more then 4.2 hours, I owned it when it came out and the CD's just done with life.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III is a turn-based conquering game that is really fun to play.
 
  Before you actually start the game, you need to choose the kind of world you want, such as choosing the size, the weather and the planet's age, after that you must choose one of the many available nations to play with, each having their unique traits.

  You can play with bots or real-life players, choosing the team in which you want them and yourself to be, thus having allies and enemies in combat.

  And as a final note, don't stare too much at the leaders, or else they are going to consume your soul, except for Theodora of course! <3

  Therefore I recommend this game to everyone interested on strategy games! :D
