title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This game is everything I want out of the Civilization series, even if a bit dated. The graphics have aged fairly well in my opinion, especially for a game from the very early 2000s. The old map-like aesthetic of the game's empire view is very nice, and the unit sprites are done very well for a game from a time with extremely limited graphical capabilities. One feature I especially love that I think shouldn't have been done away with in future Civilization games is the 'aerial view', which allows you to get an extremely detailed view of your cities.

However, even if the graphics are considered lackluster by some in this time, the soundtrack still holds up extremely well and is possibly the best soundtrack out of the entire Civilization series. From the piano-based melodies of the Medieval era to the jazzy guitar riffs of the Modern era, the soundtrack is extremely immersive and well-produced. Even some DLC scenarios have custom soundtracks, which are just as well-made as the soundtracks of the main game.

The gameplay is also well-done and it isn't too easy, nor is it too hard. The difficulty scaling in this game works well enough, and you are able to even change specifics such as AI aggressiveness, something that appears to be absent from later entries in the series. The advisors in this game are actually quite helpful and their associated menu screens allow you to easily get a detailed overview of your empire in order to best manage it. My only criticism of the more domestic side of gameplay is the way corruption works in this game; it tends to be quite rampant (especially on larger maps, and ESPECIALLY in the later stages of the game) although it can be reduced with wonders such as the Forbidden Palace and buildings such as courthouses.

Combat in this game is based off of an RNG system that works fairly well, although there is the occasional absolutely ludicrous outcome where a spearman will manage to defeat a tank. Unit promotions in this game work on four levels: conscript (the starting level for conscripted units as well as units gifted by villages), regular (the starting level for built units), veteran, and elite. Each promotion grants an extra bar of health. While much more simple than the extensive promotions in games such as Civilization 5, this system still works quite well as Civilization 3 tends to focus much more on wider-scale combat and empire management than single-unit powerhouses.

Overall, Civilization 3 is an excellent -- albeit, somewhat dated -- entry into the Civilization series. I'd probably give up both of my legs to see a remastering of this game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
My favorite Civilization title of all time. This game may be old, but I find it's graphics are just right for the genre and it does not have the cartoony look that some later titles are sometimes guilty of. Being an older title, the AI isn't always the smartest and will struggle to perform certain tasks like sea-based invasions. A huge problem with this game is its infamous RNG which has led to powerful units being killed by weaker unit (i.e. spearman kills tank). However, just play without "preserve random seed" enabled and you can just save before each battle and reload quickly to get a better result if you feel you have been cheated. Other features missing include advanced diplomacy beyond war and trade and revolutions occuring in pre-established empires (a feature lacking from most unmodded Civ titles).

The thing that makes this game my favorite Civ is the availablity of mods to customize this game to your heart's content. You can play out just about any scenario you can think of. Although a lot of files were lost when civfanatics changed a while back, there is still plenty of diverse content available. I would highly recommend the WorldWide mod for anyone looking for a much expanded version of the game. Whether you want to make small changes like add in one or two units or a custom civ, or install total conversions and scenarios, the tutorials online make it very easy to add such things in.

I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Civilization and other empire-building RTS games.


I have logged hundreds of hours on the disk version. The steam version makes it easy for me to carry this game wherever I go without having to bring disks. The only difference (and problem) I have found between the disk and Steam versions is Steam removed a lot of accesory files from the game's files, such as .exe's for vanilla Civ3 and Civ3PTW expansion. Otherwise, I have noticed little difference.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: Sid Meier's Civilization III was a major part of my childhood and, to this day, remains one of my favorite games. Unlike the more modern iterations of the game, this one goes into depth and requires some serious critical thinking and reasoning to succeed. Wartime scenarios are intense and rewarding; nothing is more satisfying than expanding your territory. Every civilization has its own unique traits that contribute to a diversified experience with each play. There are different map types to choose from as well that provide a varying experience. I'd definitely reccomend to this game to anyone, especially those that may have overlooked it while purchasing a newer civ. game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: My introduction to this amazing franchise was this ground breaking game over 12 years ago and i fell in love with the complexity, the intricacy, the miraid of play styles and sooooo much replay value. For its time the size, graphics, options and even the animation is very well done, and the music fis absolutely beautiful! If you want an easy place to start the Civ franchise, this is a nice easy entry point. Its still easy enough at this point for beginners to slip right in.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
My favorite version of Civ. Still has the old-school look of Civ II, but adds cultural boundaries and strategic resources; nothing is more fun than getting to gunpowder, oil, uranium, etc before your enemies so you can see where the good stuff is in their territories, then start a limited resource-grabbing war (or cultural takeover!) before they realize why you want that silly little square in the desert.

The only thing I miss from this version that's not in Civ2 is the ability to create cities n mountain sectors. Nothing beats a 100% defensive bonus on a city the AI is obsessing over, spending all its resources in turn after turn of fultile attack while you conquer elsewhere.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I played Civilization V and Civilization IV, but for some reason I keep getting back to Civilization III.
It is a masterpiece that stands the test of time. It is more realistic and fun with huge maps. No religion, but best Nuclear Weapons, artillery mechanic, interface is great for me and Civilopedia is the best out of all Civilizations for me. Clear and Plain to understand.
Easy game to play, yet it is harder to master.
Advisors and Leaders change clothes, depending on which era it is. Interface is more "realistic" looking and not too cartonish as the newer ones. Music is outstanding.
A lot is early on about how much you expand, but it is also much easier to get steam rolled by opponents if your cities are not defended. Sometimes less better cities is more productive and efficient. Maps play a big role, and the map editor is amazing.
Diplomacy I found the most realistic of all. World war scenario can happen very quick with mutual protections. 
Never attack anyone however with open borders, they will hate you pretty much forever, lol.
If you are not the leading in technology you can still sell them to the one that have none. If you have a technology noone has, sell it to everyone (Like worldmaps) in the same turn. Extra money is great.
Governments are a very good mechanic too. Made no sense to me Civilization IV Police State with free speech.

I recommend this game to all lovers of strategy, history and nostalgic gamers.

Edit. P.S. Ignore my steam play hours, I have probably more than a thousand.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I have probably put more time into this game than any other in my life and can call Civ III one of my all-time favorite games.

Long before Steam was a thing when Civ III was new, I spent a lot of time just playing one more turn.

Although the newer Civ games are great (Civ V, VI), the third will always be a classic to me and the one that turned me into a loyal Civ fan.

The soundtrack for this game was amazing, especially the late game music. Although it sounds very dated now, it is very well done and brings back a lot of memories.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
2 thumbs up, WAY up! Graphics are becoming dated but the fun isnt. Be aware that you may see a sunrise or two due to the "just a few more turns dilemma"

I've bought this game exactly 4 times for myself. The first copy wandered off to a friend who never got around to returning it and after a while I realized I missed it too much as I walked past the"Gold" CD version that was on sale at my local Frys which was promptly purchased. On to copy number 2, Yay! I've played that for a good long time on both Windows and Linux but finally got tired of slapping in the CD every time I wanted to play for its antiquated copy protection. Along came a Steam sale and I said 'Hello' to copy number 3. This version is slightly different than my "Gold" version (d*mn volcanoes) but still enjoyable as ever. Finally, just like clockwork, right after I bought #3 ran across another sale on that other game site that doesnt have any silly DRM on it in the first place and I was the proud owner of copy number 4. 

Add this :
KeepRes=1
to its own line in your ini file "./Civilization III Complete/Conquests/conquests.ini" to get proper widescreen support (non 4:3 aspect). This line used to be in Civ3PTW.ini but apparently got moved to this file at a later version. Depending on the version you have, this might be somewhere else too....perhaps one more directory down at "./Civilization III Complete/Conquests/Conquests/conquests.ini"

For Linux, see WineHQ for more info on how to get the "squaking" bird sound to stop once it starts. The quick fix is to turn off those sounds in options but slightly less enjoyable as it removes all the environment sounds. The short of what the fix entails is you just have to replace the bird sound file with a silent version which is easy enough to craft using something like audacity.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This game is great, but not as great as Civ5. It has pretty dated graphics and the leader animations are just downright ugly by today's standards. Some of the features are a little dated, too, like building roads to increase gold output and, of course, insane unit stacks. The music for the game isn't bad by the high standards of Civ, except the opening track which is so annoying I have to mute my speakers whenever it plays. 
This game, despite some of its dated features, is still a heck of a lot of fun. I relish the dated graphics as a "retro" Civ experience from 2001, and even the constant road-building gives your workers something to do in the later game. The "city view," which disappeared in Civ4, is something that I definitely wish would've been continued, as well as the palace view. It's also nice to be able to pass through civ borders without permission like the city-state borders from civ5, although this will anger the offended nation. I got it for $1.75 on sale and considering that's it the complete edition, it's worth every penny. 
The game is fun, cheap, and has a healthy dose of retro/nostalgic feeling for those who have played the newer Civ games. Considering that you can get this for less than two dollars, I definitely recommend this purchase.

Of course this game has a huge nostalgia factor for me, so it may not be as good to newer players, but it's a great lightweight, cheaper option for an old computer or someone who wants to try a new take on Civ.

review:

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Why, oh why did they have to stick to this stupid isometric view like in C2? What was wrong with clarity of top-down view from C1?

I guess in attempt to make the map look more realistic shape of the land is blurred so much, that it's hard to see where it actually ends. The result is quite opposite than desired, and you can't easily tell what kind of terrain is there, what would the city be covering exactly, etc. Horrible! Mountains look artificial as hell, as well ;) or, no - most of the map looks artificial and flat.
Had to play with the grid visible most of the time, otherwise couldn't see shit. Didn't get used to the grid so switched it off from time to time... and again couldn't see crap.

Other than that, it is quite good Civ game and feels like much refined C2. I liked the concept of visible and expanding borders, rather disliked the idea of culture as a winning factor (yeah right, like this could happen in this dimension), loved the concept of strategic resources and linking cities by roads/harbors/airport to use them. C3 has a good "just one more turn" factor too... but too bad you can't see shit most of the time.

Disliked because you have to choose thumb up or down. Otherwise I would rate 4/10. Not a waste of money definitely, but it doesn't have that magic and simplicity of classic C1.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I bought Civ III from the grocery store. It was in some 10 dollar PC game dump, and I saw the holy grail standing out. I picked it out and never saw anything like it. Had to beg my mom for it. That was 2004. Played it for years off and on, trying to learn everything about Civ III will drive you mad. Little did I know there was a complete edition with so much more content. 


Civ III Complete is the best Civ game. The game concepts are way ahead of it's time, and the way you have to manage you're Civ matters more than any soldier. Just opening the game and reading the Civ-pedia will leave you speechless with history lessons. I learned alot just by reading in-game. 

If you love prior Civ games before III, I reccomend you pick up this game and enjoy the good old days of Civ. This is the high point in Civ.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
When they rebuilt this game for use on modern computers, they -must- have adjusted the code in other ways as well.
There is no other reason why, on the second easiest difficulty, I have lost 28 games in a row due to the AI having massive troops, every Wonder, hordes of cities, and all this faster than I can build, no matter what I focus on.

If I try for city sprawl, the AI builds them faster than I do, and still somehow has enough time to also field a more advanced army because it's tech is better.
If I try for tech, the AI outruns me due to having many more cities feeding it's research.
If I go for military, the AI again has better tech, and more cities feeding the military.

Playing this feels a lot like the original Reach For The Stars game, where the developers outright state the game cheats in it's own favor.

I own the disks for the original game.  I used to play this, and beat it, on much harder difficulties all the time.
I refuse to believe the transition to new computers is responsible for the stupidly hard difficulty by itself.  Not on a turn based game.   Ergo, someone screwed with the code and refuses to admit it.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete

Though Civ III's age shows in its graphics and interface, the gameplay feels timeless. Civ III also stands apart from other versions of Civ. Civ III also runs on almost any computer, so It's a great game for a low powered laptop or tablet.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Originally I had some crashes with this game version (Steam), but managed to fix it. The info is at the end of the review. Civilization III Complete was one of the games I spent the most time with, and really enjoyed it. For me, it's easily one of the best 4X games ever made (at least in the time I type it).

If you did not play Civilization 3 in the past and are wondering if you should buy it - below is some basic info that should encourage you to do that.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
The pluses:

+ Lots of civilizations, each plays differently

+ Lots of different units + special military unit for each civilization

+ The AI scripts are demanding (unlike in most modern games)

+ Resources on map force you to play strategically

+ Depending on the size and type of the maps, games might differ quite a lot

+ You can play in really big maps

+ The game has fine mods that you can find on the internet

+ It's hard to stop playing it

------------------------------------------------------
The minuses:
- It's hard to stop playing it

- At higher difficulties the military victory is the most viable option (only)

- When you control most of the map it's just boring killing of the remaining weaklings

- At the industrial age, you probably control most of the map

- At higher difficulties AI is cheating

- Civilizations are not balanced (some are really good, some - really bad)

- After you learn to use workers and diplomacy, it's not that hard (but still fun)

- Old 2D game, so in native desktop resolution units and fonts might be too small

- Old 2D game, so in native game resolution units might be too big (and no widescreen)

======================================

For native desktop resolution in game:

1. Go to the Conquests folder in your Civ 3 folder conquests.ini
2. Put "keepRes=1" in conquests.ini file (without "")

======================================

Those settings should fix crashes in Windows 7 64 bit.

1. Go to the Conquests folder in your Civ 3 folder
2. Rename LSANS.FOT to -LSANS.FOT

If that does not help:
Set Windows compatibility to Windows XP Service Pack 2 and run program as administrator.

If the game runs too slow delete keepRes=1 from ini file (in Windows XP mode the game is slower)

======================================

That's it. You can now go buy the game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: So first off I'm going to start by saying even though it might show about an hour or so of playtime it does not mean I have not played this game before. I first came across this game at GameStop and I really hadn't played any games since I was young. But I needed a past time because I was dying of boredom being at home laid up in bed unable to do much. I had severely injured my back and I wasn't going to work anytime soon and the depression started to kick in. So anyways by now the game had been out for about 3 years and it looked interesting so I bought it. Went home and started playing it and it was my first time playing a strategy game so I didn't even know if I was going to like it. I started playing around lunch time by the time I know it was dinner time so took 10 minutes got my food and came back and ate while I played. By the time I knew it was freaking 6am the next day! I had never had lost track of time by that much, but man was I enjoying the game. I thought the graphics were pretty decent, the game play was very good and the UI was also good. Of course it was the first time I've had played a game with an in game Civilopedia and I thought that was awesome. The other thing I miss from Civilization III that has not been added to any other Civilization since is building your capital building when your citizens were happy you were able to add one section at a time until you finished upgrading your building. I thought that was fun, even though it was a very simple and quick thing. By the time Civilization IV came out I had around 3500 hours invested in this game and I still have the original disk I bought, but I went ahead and bought it on Steam because they had a very good deal on Civ III, IV and Colonization which I already have the other two also. But I want to keep those disks from getting any damage and besides Steam keeps a running track of your gaming time. So I can safely say this game is what got me back into gaming and becoming a full time gamer. I DO RECOMMEND THIS GAME, EVEN THOUGH IT'S AN OLDER GAME. Keep gaming.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
All right. I got this game from a friend sometime around 2012, I think. I played it for a bit but honestly, I had trouble getting into it. A lot had changed from Civilization II and I never really caught on to all the differences.

Picked it up during the Steam Black Friday sale on Thanksgiving. I gave it a whirl. At first, I had the same feelings I did last time I played all those years ago. It wasn't CivII, and the strategies that worked for me then were failing me now. It didn't help that there wasn't a tutorial or a manual of any kind, and the Civilopedia is not the most user-friendly interface, although it's critical to understanding all of the game mechanics the AI employs.

I played on Chieftain for a while, just trying to get a handle on the game mechanics, but now I'm bored of chieftain. Too easy. Once you learn and begin to understand the game mechanics, this is a pretty great game. That said, it's virtually impossible to win if you don't constantly expand and build one city after another. I mean, that is all you will do. Build and build and build. If you don't, the AI will and you'll lose. Pretty much the only way to win is to begin building a ton of cities in the early parts of the game.

I did like the implementation of cultural borders, and how borders clash against one another. The cultural conversion tool was also pretty cool, where cities could rebel and join your forces because they realized that their own culture was lifeless. So it's a pretty good game, and definitely worth the price for my 46 hours (and growing).

I do have to say, though, that a couple of the leader choices are really dumb. Mahatma Gandhi was not a leader of the Indian nation. Although he championed the move for India's independence, making him the face of India is weird, because he was a guru and not a general. And Jeanne d'Arc leading the French? She was a teenager and a peasant who, by her own confession, never even used her sword in combat. They could have chosen Charlemagne or Napoleon Bonaparte, but Joan! Kinda silly!

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Still as good of a game as I remember it from my childhood, it's age shows a little, but for $5 (and potentially even less) it still provides that "one more turn" mentality. I probably sunk at least 200 hours into my local libraries copy, so when I saw it was on steam, it was a no brainer purchase.

Having played Civ 5, I have to say that the portraits of the rulers convey far more emotion, at least in my eyes, than the full set pieces of Civ 5. The barbarians have multiple AI options and can be absolutly brutal. Certain civilzations have certain traits which affect what actions trigger golden ages. You get to upgrade your palace in a way that actually changes the way it looks on the city screen. Also there is a city screen where you get a detailed overview of your city and all the wonders you built. As opposed to Civ 5's jam packed 3D model of your city.

Age helps, in a way, since with todays operating systems the turns are lightning fast, even with troop movement.

I know I have my nostagia blinders on, but I really like this game, despite whatever flaws I cannot see. I suspect that anyone who likes these kinds of games and doesn't mind the lack of 4k graphics, will definitely get their money's worth.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: My hours played do not reflect my time on this game, because I had it long, long before it was out on Steam.  What game could better deserve the 'Test of Time' award (except, perhaps, Civ 2: Test of Time, but that's not on Steam).  Civ 3 has a timeless appeal that will bring old players back, and give new players (who, perhaps, have played a more recent Civ) a look at the glorious history of the series.  The beginnings of National Wonders, the Worker/Settler split, rivers on tile borders, rather than on tiles.  All these and more began with Civ 3.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Civilization III is one of my long-time favorites. It's fairly complex, very interesting, (from a historical standpoint). The graphics still look quite appealing, even after 15 years. 

The only advancements I've noticed in modern Civ games include, religion, more complex foreign policy, and better AI. I should also mention multiplayer, as the multiplayer aspect of this game died with Game Spy, unless you were to organize a game with friends.

This is still a great game that I would reccomend to fans of the Strategy genre of games, and, I know this is being overused of recent, but I believe, this is truly a game that stands the test of time.

Picked this up during a Steam sale a while back. I'd never really been a fan of 4X titles. This game single-handedly changed that:

Pros:
[1] Simple intuitive user interface
[2] Loads of custom maps and scenarios to play out
[3] Loads of civilizations to try out with each feeling slightly different from the others

Cons:
[1] Management of units becomes tedious during last game
[2] Competent but passive AI in lower difficulty settings

A definite must have in any strategy collection.... And it still stands the test of time.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Sid Meier’s Civilization III is a 4x strategy game, that means the objective of the game is to eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate to win. First off, the game takes some time to get the hang of the concept, but it also just takes time to play. A game could last anywhere from 30 minutes to multiple years. I first read the manual for the game which did help out. It told me of keyboard shortcuts that I never actually used. It also explained to me the basics of the game so when I started my new game I wasn’t completely lost. (This is coming from somebody who hasn't played any strategy games.) The first 30 minutes of my first game I wasted my turns walking around then finally building a city. I played as the Iroquois, they are proficient in agriculture, though I started producing warriors and getting very aggressive. My neighbors killed me and within an hour my first game was over. My second game ended much quicker, within 30 minutes my tiny city was captured. I felt very lost within the first turns of my first game. I felt the game didn’t do a very good job explaining what to do. I just felt a desire to discover the dark parts of the map because it didn’t look very good to me. However, I did find the advisors that would pop up and tell me information that I found very useful and helpful. In this way the game was able to help me assimilate myself with it’s complicated mechanics. 
One interesting mechanic in the 4x strategy game is its robust diplomacy system. There are many treaties, alliances, trade opportunities, agreements to be made, and wars to be waged. On my current playthrough I am a militaristic expansionist Roman empire I encountered the Aztecs and began fighting a war with them.  Upon seeing the I could overthrow them the Aztecs asked for a peace treaty which I agreed to. From there on out the Aztec and I created a rite of passage where we would be able to cross each other's land. However, I plan on expanding cities and surrounding them then I will take over their cities and kill them. This diplomacy system is a major part of my strategy to win the game. This will play a consequential role of my playthrough of this game. 
In general I have never been a big fan of strategy games, however I did find myself enjoying this game to a certain extent. I don’t expect to be putting too much time into the game anymore, but I can say that my time spent with it has not been all negative.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
If you're looking for ludicrous and war-mongering AI, as well as the ability to make your civilization happy without a circus and other buildings that provide happiness, this is the game for you!

In all seriousness, this is a great game. It is 100% worth the $1.24 you pay when it goes on sale! It is very easy to manage your cities' happiness and production! With Civ III, you can que production items, unlike Civ V, which makes the game enjoyable. As well as allows you to have very productive cities. The way it makes that aspect of the game more enjoyable is that you don't have to click on the choose production icon every few turns. However, it sometimes likes to just switch to needless outdated military units after it runs out of production items in a que. Another nice feature of this game is the selecting how you want your game to be set up. It allows you to choose how old the earth is when you start the game. As well as has a few more features that are absent in Civ 5.

The only cons to this are the aforementioned AI, and playing it on a newer computer. The AI are typically kind of crazy when it comes to deals, and get really annoyed if you decline them. Which typically leads to war with them eventually. I seem to have a problem where the AI all declare war with me. Also, the AI expand their civilizations really fast, so if you buy this, make sure to settle as many cities as possible in the beginning of the game! Although that really applies to any Civ Game. Finally, Civ 3 seems to run too fast on newer computers, and it will skip through some animations. 

Other than that, this is a really great game! Especially when it is slightly more expensive than a pack of gum!

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
If you're looking for a Civilization game try either Civ IV or Civ V, both are better than this.

The combat feels too random and the AI seems to be overly aggressive (Something is wrong when someone like Gandhi demands tribute and refusing makes them declare war on you.) The AI also is very expansionist, creating new cities whenever it can.

I found no tutorial, so I had to learn how to play the game myself through trial and error.

On the bright side, it comes with its own scenario editor.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: Personally this is my favorite turn based strategy. The game is playable for anybody and is very addicting if a person likes to be in control of things. What I like the most, is ability to grow really big, to name stuff as one wants and to play on real World maps. Editor is really simple btw. AI is kind of not really good, but it's challenging on high levels due to bonuses to AI. Also, there is a city count limit on a map which is 512 I think and the game has kind of built in minimal turn waiting time. I have tested this with some members on the community, and it seems that game code doesn't allow for faster operation, regardless of PC hardware one is using. No matter what CPU/RAM/GPU one has, two very powerful cores or 8 core CPU (since the game utilizes only one core by default), the speed of the slowest turn will be the same. Which is considerable, when you have full map of civs, dip relations and modern units.

review:
I've played this game since it came out, on and off, over the years.  It's wonderful.  To me, Civ 2 is the archetype.  This one is Civ 2 with a modern look and sensical changes/additions.

This game can be very relaxing but can also be drenched in anxiety and frustration.  The AI cracks me up...  sometimes they feel like real human thinkers but other times they're just barbarian lunatics!

I'm running this thing on a Macbook Pro through CrossOver software.  With a few tweaks, it works great!  Which is amazing because it's the only way I can play the game via my computer.  I also have Civ IV which is also great, but I find myself playing III whenever I feel the urge.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Here's what I think of this game, I'll compare it to Civ 5 since most people consider that to be the best Civ game.

Music: Both Civ 5 and Civ III have fantastic soundtracks as with pretty much all Civ games. CIV 5's soundtrack is better, but that doesn't mean this soundtrack isn't worth listening to. 

Diplomacy: The diplomacy here in Civ III, in my opinion is better. You can trade maps technologies, change how agressive the AI is. The AI does get quite a bit agressive once you get to medium agressiveness although.

Scenarios: The scenarios here in Civ III are quite interesting. We have Rise of Rome, Fall of Rome, Napoleanic Europe, WW2 in the pacific, etc. I honestly can't choose between Civ 5 and 3 in terms of which had better scenarios.

War: And here is where we start to see the flaws of Civ III. There are certain units made for attacking, defending, and seige units. The seige units must be protected otherwise they will be either captured or destroyed immediately, and the attacking units are vulnerable to counterattack. Defending units ensure your cities are protected and your attacking armies. This part of war, I liked, It made sure I don't just build completely one type of unit. 
Cities are instantly captured if there is no unit inside. I wasn't as fond of this as the unit diversity, but it was tolerable at least.
But then their's the battle system. It's luck based, which I have a burning hatred for. I could attack a spearman one time with an archer and not take any damage, while another time, a defending spearmen exactly the same as the other one could take out my archer, without taking any damage. How does that make any sense? I get it it's an old game an all, but come on.
Also the AI seem way too powerful. I met Scandinavia on turn 2 and it already said his forces outnumbered mine.

CIv 5 definetly, has better war mechanics.

Barbarian encampment and ruins/friendly encampments: Whether you love 'em or hat 'em these guys are around, some encampment are friendly and will give you something like gold or a settler to give you a huge early game boost. and of course the hostile. You can make the hostile encampments non existant, sedentary, normal, roaming or raging. Since there is more option than Civ 5, I'd say these are slightly better.

Civilization balance: Civilization 5 isn't exactly balanced, (Babylon is much better, is pretty much better every aspect compared to let's say the Iroqouis). Civ's are more balanced here. Each Civ have a unique unit, 2 free technologies and 2 bonus'. Military bonus' allow you to build stronger armies faster, science allows you to build science buildings faster, religious allows you to build cultural building faster, etc. In my opinion the two best are science and religious (Which Babylon ironically has both XD). Besides that Civ's are quite balanced besides early game Unique units (I'm looking at you bowmen)

Victory types: Time victory is always on here, which I don't like (although you can push back the counter for time victory to kick in) cultural victoy revolves around how much culture you can get in either one city or your entire empire, dominatuion requires you to own at certain percentage of the world's population or land area, conquest is to eliminate all rival civilizations., wonder is to build a certain amount of wonders, diplomatic is to get people to vote for you once the UN is built, and space race to leave this filthy planet. All good, although most of the time you will win by either cultural or time.

Graphic: I don't really care for graphics much, but the graphic here are at best, pleasing to the eye and at worst, tolerable.

Conclusion: CIV 5 is obviously better, but Civ 3 is extremely enjoyable also, I have many hours into this, and many more will be put into playing this. I know the flaws I listed here aren't going to be changed unless everyone at Firaxis gets high. I haven't seen any bugs, just a great game.

I rate this 9/10- Aged beautifully, like a gem.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This maybe the cheatingest game I've ever played. Literally, at the later stages, it is essentially unplayable, because either your units are so nerfed or theirs are so boosted that nothing can be done.

You manage your cities perfectly. You carefully build a technological advantage. You've diplomatically played enemies against enemies.

And now it's time. Your tanks are ready to move on the helpless city guarded only by a few men with spears.

But there is a problem. For some reason, your tanks lose. So you send in the the airforce to soften things up. But, again, men with spears win the day. So, you park a battleship off the coast and start shelling. No damage. No damage.

Wait, an enemy trireme rows up armed with arrows... and sinks your battleship.

That's when you realize. The game is a cheating piece of shit.

[tr]
[td][h1]AUDIO[/h1][/td]
[td]Catchy[/td]
[td][h1]VISUAL[/h1][/td]
[td]Simplistic[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]

[td]Addictive[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][h1]CRAVING[/h1][/td]
[td]Board Games[/td]
[td][h1]ON SALE[/h1][/td]
[td]Frequently[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[b]PROS: [/b]On Mar 16, this game received a much-needed update to get rid of the nonfunctioning Gamespy multiplayer! Ugh, what a relief! This is my favorite installment of the Civ series. The game has a slew of nice preferences to choose from, even including an aid for the color blind.

[b]CONS: [/b] New to the game? Go into the options and turn the tutorial on. It's starts as off, for some reason. The cutscenes look horrible because of age and stretching. Resolutions are rough. Compared to modern installments, the opponent civs act rather erratically, to the point of being nonsensical. There is no balancing, so some Civs are OP and others you would ideally never play.

[b]WORTH: [/b]This is my favorite installment of the series, of course I think it's worth full-price. You may want to consider a discount though, if you're used to later installments. To the average player that lacks nostalgia, this is just the game you know and love but with less features.

[b][u]OVERALL:[/u] [/b] It's very easy to lose track of time with this game. It's great fun and I'd recommend it to anybody looking for a good "board game" style game on Steam, since there aren't many. It's certainly more simple than four or five, but has been my favorite installment of the series.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
The series ended here, as far as I'm concerned. Now, Civ 4 was a good game, and while the less that is said about Civ 5 the better (if you ask me), in my mind Civ 3 was the epitome of the Sid Meier vision for the series and the greatest achievement of aesthetics, style, pacing and general gameplay - as far as Civ gameplay could go.

I think this has a lot to do with the predecessors. Civilization: Call to Power was an epic computer game, surpassing and extremely entertaining. Alpha Centauri was of course one of the very greatest titles the genre has ever seen, encorporating gameplay additions and features - so much recorded voice acting~ - that still feel fresh and ingenious to this day. It was into this setting of established 2D, top down turn based strategy excellence that Civ 3 had to plonk, and what a plonk it was.

How did it work so well? Well it was the way the game juxtaposed itself against it's lineage as much as the way it reproduced and refined it that really rung true with me. Civilzation 3 was all about resolution, refinement, aesthetics and staid excellence. The pacific colours, the fantastic drawn visions of your cities, the subtly faux-3D border markers, the movements of the characters, sounds and the pacing of the game were all just totally lovely touches that made this experience feel high quality and timeless.

Playing it today reveals a game that is completely succesful as a final installment in a series, even though the series itself continued on into the age of 3D. There are flaws of course - in end game especially the dominated maps completely cede any kind of influence over gameplay to your railways, aircraft and ICBMs, the voice acting of Alpha Centauri would have been really great here (it was used for Civ 4, famously, with Leonard Nimoy granting that game degrees of cultural magic that few computer games enjoy) and one could say that consequently the gameplay gets a bit stale towards the later stages of a long game, but it is what happens in the interim - especially the first three quarters of the span of civilization you navigate - that is a really wonderful experience, worth any price.

Play it!

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I have civ5 complete too. Like some of the other reviews I found the game fairly different from civ5. Definitely worth the buy ($1.37 on sale). Not having the culture group stuff from civ 5 makes the game alot better. Another up compared to civ 5 is that it doesnt have the fancy graphics, so I can run it on my work laptop (which has no dedicated gpu) [civ 5 to go? lel].

I find the whole idea of *clicking on my temple to add an upgrade (all visual?)* pretty pointless and dumb. I literally just hover my touchpad over the whole screen till i hear a sound, then click and escape. It was pretty annoying to 

The time it takes to finish a game is both a pro and con. If you are a time sensitive person I would suggest you turn off move animations for all units because you will leterally have your eye pop out waiting for allt he units to move at the end. Some of the other default settings also made the game annoying to play. In particular, if you have units which are fortified or in alert stances, the turn may very well pass away under the default setting unless you do some annoying repetitive camerfa movement. There was a setting to wait at the end of ever turn to make this easier, I'm totally fine hitting space bar or enter at the end of every turn then watch things happen in a way i didn't want it.

I still have to learn about some other mechanisms in this game before I comment further. I'll probably add more next time i stop by.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
My Dad thinks that games are a waste of time and that one can have much more fun and growth from reading Thackery or Trollope. That being said, he must have put in several thousand hours into this game since he bought it for me around my 6th-odd birthday in 2001. Our primay form of bonding is talking Civ strategy. 

He has no interest in 4, 5, BE or anything like that. Says they're not interesting like this one is. I'm inclined to agree. I think that Civ 3 is the essence of 4X, and that any designer wanting to know what makes 4x games great,  should play this obsessively. There are a few things here and there that I think could have been expanded on- such as plague- and the fact that some civilizations simply have uninspired Unique Units with bland mechanics. Nevertheless, one of my favourite games ever. Now that Civ 6 is happening, I do hope that Meier et al look back to this one, for inspiration, on how a truly grand 4X should be.

I own 3, 4 and 5, and still play 3 from time to time because of things I enjoy in it that I don't find in the other two.

review: I have played this game since it came out brand new back in the day (my hours don't reflect the amount of time I've put into it) and I still believe that it's one of the best games ever made.  Out of everything I've played, I come back to this game over and over again and am constantly amazed at the replayability it brings.  It's always different and interesting to see how the enemy will attack you and what it takes to defend yourself/territory.  Taking over the world is my favorite, but may take days.  If you blow it then just start a whole different one.  It's easy to understand and learn but very complicated to master.  It's right up there with Chess and Axis and Allies in my book of classics. I've found nothing else quite as great........

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Civ 3 Complete on sale for $1.24 so I buy it since I recall how great it was years ago.  I am a big fan of Civ 4 & Civ 5 with all the expansions.  And I am delaying getting a new PC until I know the system requirements for Civ 6.  Still I realize that there was a lot I missed from Civ 3:  Artillery that doesn't suffer damage.  The people's portraits in the city display (I liked Civ I's  full figurines even better).  The fashion progression for world leaders and the population.  (Nineteenth Century attire looks good on everybody; I don't know why).  Single figure unit graphics.  And extremely good graphics for the system requirements.
     And the world is massive.  Civ 5, by giving every unit at least 2mp, really shrank the world.  
     Units simply gain more hits points on promotion; no decision on how to specialize.
     Music that expresses the time frame of the turn.  Civ 5's music is just as varied but seems 
     designed as background music.
Of course it all depends on what one wants from a Civ game.  But if it goes on sale again for $1.24 that's not much of a gamble.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Absolutely amazing game. I've played all linear [i]Civilization[/i] games save for Civ 2 and this has by far been my favourite. I really wish they didn't stray from the feel of the first 3 Civ games, I'm really not a fan of the feel of Civ 5, but alas the masses seem to disagree with me. 

I don't want the bland interface of the fourth and fifth games, I want character, and my loyal advisors to guide me.

I don't want to set my political civic 'Police State' and my economic civic to 'Central Planning'; I don't want to take whatever 'social policy' tree (with permanent effects + no drawbacks) or adopt the 'Order' ideology.
I want to use the 'Communism' government and have my advisors refer to me as 'Comrade' as I free to the proletariat of the world from the bourgeosie and the 'Fascist' Aztecs!

The character of the game, the way events and history play out, managing your empire and waging war, etc. is simply really something and it really seems to have been lost with the new Civ games. And the sad thing is, it has so much potential for future games with more fleshed-out content, features, etc.

Definite 9/10

Once you're mentally set that this is the moment your life turns around, download the game, and by golly have some fun.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: A very confusing game to play if it is your first time playing a Civ or other turn based strategy game. With enough perseverance, you'll learn the ropes though. While a more simple game than its successors Civ 4 and Civ 5, this game is extremely complex but still wildly fun and addicting. It doesn't make my computer slow at all and is fun to play alone, especially in an airport or on a sick day. It can, however, still be enjoyed just as much in 5 minute intervals as a pick-up-and-play game. 5/5 would recommend to anyone with patience and an appreciation for historical accuracy.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I understand, it's just not for me. 

When I was a child, I played this on and off constantly and never figuring out what I was doing. I played Diablo 2 around the same time and also didn't know what I was doing. 

This complicated empire micromanaging game is an old classic that many people remember, be it from watching one of your relatives playing or being that relative playing. You must manage large armies and cities while trying to expand your kingdom across the world. Disease, famine, civil unrest and poverty are just some of the factors you will have to deal with with trying to be the greatest empire. Doing things all the time is what will get you ahead, and failing over and over learning what does and doesn't work is the tutorial. Hardcore RTS is defined by the Civilization franchise.

I never really understood this game and I still don't. I never really enjoyed micromanage games as they posed too much stress for me to correctly enjoy them. This is personal and won't sway the game itself. 

This game is for people who love watching massive amounts of action going on at the same time with rediculous difficulty options and really good customization for world generation. For being this old, it holds its complication and difficulty really well. If you love this kind of stuff, then it's a no brainer and if you have never heard of this or just faintly remember it from long ago, make sure you Youtube some videos to make sure its your type of game.

It's not my kinda game, but it might be yours.

Personal Rating 1/5

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: There pretty much isn't a bad game in this strategy franchise. The concept is simple: Pick your civ, play through history, win... But the execution is VERY complex. You win in different ways depending on which country you are and which does what. If you try to dominate the world as a civ that specializes in researching technology, Well you're gonna have a bad time. You could be doing amazing for a few hours and a few hundred turns into the game, but make one bad decision or one bad move and you could cripple your empire. This game has hours among hours of replayability and content, and it's relatively cheap. If you get it on sale it's dirt cheap. And I personaly think this Civ is a little easier to pick up and learn then Civ 5, but maybe not everyone will agree with me. But this is a true gem in the strategy genre. Easily a must own for any fan. 9/10.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
The Steam edition of Civilization III does not work correctly on Windows 7, which kind of defeats the purpose I had in getting it to begin with. Unlike the retail CD version of the game from years ago, it installs without hassle. What it doesn't do without hassle is run correctly. Every time I've started a game, I've encountered audio bugs where the music stops and the sound effects run an in endless loop like crickets. Heaven forbid you ever try to quit the game, either, because it will not only crash, but lock up your entire monitor and not let task manager launch over it.

If a game is going to be sold on steam, I expect some kind of work to be done to make it compatible with current operating systems. If Gog.com can do it, so can Valve.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:

To me, this will always be the pinnacle of the Civilization series. 

I don't know how many hours of my life went into playing this game since I started out with the CD version before buying a copy on steam when I lost the orginal disc, but I doubt I'll find another game that can entertain me for as long as this one did.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
So many many many years ago I played the first CIV game. I loved it. Barely understood it as I was too young but I loved it. Lost the game at some point and didn't play the other CIV games until I bought CIV4 during a Steam sale. While the graphics improved a lot from the first game I did not enjoy the game as much. It was rather simple and straight forward. So now during another sale I decided to buy CIV3 as a lot of people are saying it's the  best version. A few hours in and I have to say I like this one better then 4. The game is a bit more challenging even on easy mode and I am just having a fun time creating my own civilizations. That however doesn't mean there aren't any downsides. Some things do not make sense like older units being stronger then newer units. Then there is the little glitch that you will constantly be aware of and that is that it looks like the game is freezing at the end of every turn. It just freezes for a few seconds and then continues but it is a bit of a pain. So far I have no had it shut down on me completely like I am reading in other peoples reviews but who knows it might just happen at some point. Honestly for the money I paid for it I won't complain much. It would have cost me more to get the cd version though I wouldn't have the glitch. My opinion? Totally worth playing and if you don't mind waiting a few seconds at the end of every turn get the steam version. If you do then buy the cd version. Have a lot of fun with it! 

P.S. having the chance to build your own castle is something I missed in CIV 4 glad to see it in CIV 3 :)

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This is the first Civilization game that I have ever played. And I have nothing but pleasant memories about it.

It includes all the basic mechanics that define a Civ game. But it hasn't aged very well. The interface is archaic and it's all 2D (except for leader animations). Not that it matters much for a strategy game, but still. 

Civ4 and Civ5 have much more to offer, so it's probably worth playing Civ3 only for nostalgic value. Although, I miss palace customisation and City View with wonders in the later games. Another cool feature is that the leader appearance and title change with each next era

Anyway, if you can get over occasional crashes, you will still spend hours building your empire, but, as I've said, with newer version on the market, Civ3 is mostly for veterans and those who'd like a more challenging game than Civ5.

My overall rating: 7/10

(-2 for crashes, -1 for not being as good as Civ5)

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This game is dated, and while it does run on the more modern OS's out there, it isn't well optimized.  I found the game running at a steady 8 frames per second on my old Windows 8 machine.  However, most gamers here use PCs powered by 32 gigs of ram and NVIDIA's latest graphics card which requires the heat of the sun to forge properly, so it might run better on your Windows 7 or 8 computer.

The game itself was a staple in my childhood.  I had many hours of fun with it, even though I sucked at it as a kid.  Now, I can lay out a strategy, and retaliate easily when the enemy declares war.

The game itself has quite a bit going on.  You have to balance your gold economy, which can be a challenge as you progress in scientific research, military power, and additions to your city.  You have to make use of the terrain around you, which itself can be a gamble.  You might get everything you need under one generated map, and then get completely fucked by another generated map.  There is a lot to cover, most of which I'll leave you to see for yourself.

In the end, there's a lot of content, and for its current price, its a great game.  If you like strategy games, then you'll probably love this game.  9/10.

review:

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
It may seem a bit anemic compared to the later installments but I find CivIII is still worth picking up to at least try if you're a Civ fan.

While not deep, this 4x experience is very refined, you really do have to play exactly to your Civ's strengths if you want any hope to succeed in the higher difficulties- there is no real catch all method. People may have complained about bombardment and bombers being Op since they can straight up kill units but I find this adds a lot more tactical complexity to war, especially in the mid Ind. age where it really reflects how much warfare at that time was based around defensive positions.

The campaigns within are straight up the best of any vanilla Civ game, Rise of Rome, the Middle Ages and the Age of Discovery are excellent, and hell the Pacific Theatre almost could've been its own game!

Finally, it may be a personal thing, but I've always preferred the isometic display here to the 3d graphics of 4, 5 and Beyond.

And as a small side note, because of how cheap this game is now it can be an effective litmus test to see if you'll even enjoy Civ games, so there's that.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
An old one, I can see why it was well liked when it first came out. Not so aged that it is horrible now, but cheap and worth the price. I decided to first try out the series with this one recently and I enjoyed the game. Enough that I am looking to play 4 in the near future.

The army movement and combat isn't deep, but there is enough that you need to be sure where you want the armies to go and make sure you have enough strength at the places you need them. Otherwise you can lose land to an invasion you weren't prepared for. Tech trees are nice, lots of tech through the different ages, some of which reward being the first to research it. The wonders have some game influence, so they are not just decorations. Like all empire games you need to manage your resources between development, research and military. You can also make land, sea and air units as they become available

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Bought this originally when PC games came out in those big square boxes, and to be fair it does show its age. The graphics aren't enivable at all because, well, it is nearly 14 years old. It crashes sometimes too. There is quite a learning curve, but after a while you do get through it. The AI is random or too predictable at times, if they plop a stack randomly into your territory and refuse to leave, they're 90% going to declare war. Playing on easier levels, outsmarting the AI is fairly formulaic, aggressive expansion for the first half, strategically stealing all resources and then ploughing through them all. Small maps are too small, and if you create a massive map (which you can do in the editor, which itself has a learning curve) there is a city limit of 450. The game reaches its limit, but by that point each turn is so long, why bother. Naval conflict is always a bit piddly too. 

But really the base game has a simple enough format that its almost like a PC version of Monopoly. You can play it again and again, no fancy 3D experience or anything, the graphics really don't impede gameplay. 14 years later its still perfectly playable and, importantly, provides a fun and varied experience. Each game comes out wildly different from the last one, and every time you play a new challenge will arise. The randomized earths created offer nearly infinite variety and eliminate any boredom you could experience with similar games. I can easily play this game for hours and hours. Similar to Paradox games, once you start a campaign its hard to finish, there is enough variety in maps you always want to do something else. Games can easily go far into the future, and with some mods you can add some variety onto the existing game's timeline. 

9/10 game!

Just play it.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I'm going to start by saying I'm not a strategy 4X kind of guy. I'm terrible at them. This one is no exception. Additionally, I bought this a week before losing internet for an extended period of time, so my hours are waaay off.

That being said, I've been playing since 2011 when I was looking for cheap games on Steam. To my surprise, I noticed one of the five dollar games had a 90/100 on Metacritic whereas many other games had a 70/100 at best (I cared about Metacritic back then, sue me.) so I knew I just had to have it. I had no idea what I was getting into.

To this day, this one of my most cherished purchases on Steam, and by far my favorite strategy game EVER. I played Civ 5 for a bit, but despite its evergrowing modding scene, I always come back to this one. The graphics still look good to this day (Save for the civ portraits, and dated resolutions. Yuck), and the music will forever dominate space on my music player of choice. 

Buy it at full price.

For this reason its really REALLY annoying even if you waste ten hours or more on a single game in multiplayer you wont even make it half way to the end of the game.

However this game in single player story mode is another game all together you can bust hour a whole game in a single day and boy is it fun in single player but the whole reason most people play this game is to play with friends so if you are after it to play alone this will suck up your time and will be enjoyable but if you are looking to play with a friend. title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: This is the game that started my love of the Civilization series, and strategy games in general.   I have fond memories sitting down and spending hours playing this game, even though I didn't fully understand it's mechanics at the time.  As I grew older, this was my favorite game for a number of years.  This game holds it's own in just about every key aspect, even compared to the newer installments of the Civilization series.  Online multiplayer? You bet!  Unique mechanics and smart AI for it's age? Yup! Good graphics for a game made in 2001? Heck yes!  The replay value of this game makes even Civ 5 blush.  I've been playing this game since 2006, and I still never get bored of it.  Every scenario pans out differently, and no two games are ever quite the same.  Even to this day, I prefer this over Civ 5.  Maybe it's the nostalgia talking, but this is definitely my favorite Civ game of the lot.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Building on the classic Civilization II, Civ III introduces several new game mechanics including expanding City borders & also for the first time animated units. The player starts off in the year 4000 BC with a small group of settlers and some basic knowledge of road building, irrigation & farming. After choosing the site of their first City the player then has to explore and expand their empire to other locations. The ideal placement of a City would be close to natural resources & luxuries, this will help increase trade, production & happiness of the citizens. Connecting City's via roads also increases trade and the sharing of resources / luxuries across your empire. During the early game roaming Barbarians may cause problems along your borders and any unprotected units or land will be either captured or pillaged. As you progress through the centuries you will eventually meet other Civilizations. Some of these will be friendly and willing to trade, others more hostile and may attack you completely unprovoked. You have the opportunity to influence the opinions of other empires by your actions towards them, giving them gifts or trading technology is usually a way to get on their good side. Later in the game you can also forge an alliance with certain empires in the form of a mutual protection pact. This is especially useful during times of War to help seal victory over your enemies. The game ends in one of six ways, the most traditional being conquest (destroying all opponents). The Space race victory occurs when any Civilization completes and launches a Space Ship to Alpha Centauri. Other victory types are Cultural, Diplomatic & Domination. If the game ends and no one is victorious by any of these, the game uses a "histograph" to determine the winner by points.

This is one of my all time favourite games, though Civ IV has more depth by adding religion, unit promotions and other special abilities. I still prefer this version to any other.

There are no in game options for changing to widescreen resolutions but if you do the following: goto your Steam/SteamApps/Common/Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete/Conquests folder then find the file called conquests.ini. Right click to edit the file then goto the bottom and add the line Keepres=1 this will force the game to your monitors resolution.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Years ago I owned this game, and had long lost it. It was a game I liked and so when I found here on Steam, I figured it would be worth it to get it again. 

Publishers shouldn't sell things that they are too lazy to tweek to modern comps / operating systems. Should players really have to google fixes for all the slightly older games sold here? IF a publisher released something for free, no update would be understandable. On games where they charging though, take the 10 mins to update the code so it runs ok vs making playing spend much longer fixing it.

I'm running windows 7, and when I start a new Civ3 game, I start with 7 duplicate leaders of my Civ. I have no idea why 7 Abraham Lincolns are doing running around, and with a big bug right from the get go, I have no trust of the game. I did google for it and couldnt find anything for it. After spending 30 mins googling and fixing other things just to get the game going and then going in windowed mode, that was enough. With the 2 hour limit on playtime for refunds, I am not going to push my luck on a game with questionable functionality.

I tapped out at 46 min and submitted for a refund.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
ive spent hundreds of hours expanding the german empire, wiping out the human population with my vastly superior military technology. panzers vs muskets. nukes versus cannons.
I overtook europa, then swept through asia and africa in one foul swoop. the bolshevik menace is dead and bleeding, while japan slaughters the chinese and overtakes the pacific and australia.
the global blitzkrieg soon smashed though the new world, annihilating the capitalistic American pigs. 
the mushroom clouds of the deutch nuclear doomsday device rises above new york, Los Angeles, DC, Moskow, and Mecca
I am drunk on power.
drunk on the deaths of hundreds of millions of digital innocents.
when will the senseless slaughter stop?
when I see the impossible outcome of the civilization ive built up crumble beneath my feet from the inside, the fate so many empires before me have faced... the last society left on this planet...
the end of civilization...3

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
From the very beginning, every mainline edition of the Civilization series has gotten an average of a 90-95% user approval rate which is a greater approval rate than that normally ascribed to civilization itself. This could be due to the fact that the Civilization seies simply soars while civilization itself seems to soar and stink in equal measure. Then again, it could be that the game of Civilization simply appeals to the inner narcissist lurking somewhere within us all. After all, how often is it you can be elected ruler of your nation by popular acclaim, rule them in a governmental form of your choice, eventually rise to rule to world, establish Earth's first off world colony, and live for centuries. I have to admit that is slightly more ambitious than my own real world expectations, but I do have an eye on the North American continent. Consider yourself warned.

Now don't get me wrong here. I am not trying to say that Civilization is the best turn based, civ building, strategy game ever. That would be unfair to all those games I have not gotten around to trying. What I can say is that it is by far the best I have ever played, and narcissist that I am, I will try most anything that gives me a shot at world domination.

The Civilization series is up to Civ-5 at this point, but Civ-3 is a game which endures the times, remains comparable to like games of more recent production, and holds a special place in my heart when compared to the newer versions of this long running classic. Later editions of this game introduce elements which alter the play style and base strategy of the game, but while I believe that Civ-4 & 5 remain true to the original construct to a large degree, it is Civ-3 which most closely  resembles the original. In fact, it is exactly like the original, but with greater user options, and smoother game play. 

If you have been thinking about giving this series a try, Civ-3 is a great place to start. With the release of Civ-5, the Steam price for Civ-3 is a mere $5.00 which in my opinion makes it one of the best bargains in the entire Steam Library. Just one run through of this game will keep you occupied for longer than the run time of a long movie, and when was the last time you got into a movie theatre for &5.00 eh? I began playing this game when it first came out for PC in the 90's, continue to play it to this day, and played Civ-1 & 2 before that. How's that for a testament for long term replayability? I simply could not recommend another game of this type more highly.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: This game has, by far, taken more of time than any other.  In fact I am on my fourth, hopefully final, copy of it.  I orignally was gifted a 3 part CD version of the game from a neighbor who never was into computer games and did not want it.  I played CIV3 nonstop, I would sit in class fantasizing about the game, I would go to sleep dreaming about the game and I still to this day reminisce about specific games I had played close to ten years ago.  I was so hooked that my father took the discs and snapped them in half.  Months of stellar behavior later I managed to earn another copy on my birthday, which was quickly destroyed a month later due to an average of ten hours a day, and 16 hours on the weekend.  I was able to get another disc copy without my parents knowing but I could not control my addiction, causing them to find out about my new copy and promptly destorying it.  Now, able to do things on my own, I bought my latest version on steam for no other reason that I do not feel complete without knowing I have it.  Honestly, this game does not play as well as CIV5 but if you are looking for a changeup, buy it.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
General - 8.0
Sid Meier's Civilization is one of the greatest game franchises ever, it's a landmark for every turn-based strategy game. The name itself tells what the game is about, you pick one civilization, select a location to start, select CPU controlled civilizations and settings for that specific map. Your job is to make your civilization meet any of the victory conditions, which can be through science, military, culture, diplomacy, points, etc. The first game of the series I played was Civ II, back in 2001, which instantly made me a fan since then. However I skipped Civ III at its time, and that is what made me buy it many years later. I paid around 1USD for the game just to see what I missed, and unfortunately, not much. Don't get me wrong, it's a great game, but if you played Civ IV, in my opinion, there is nothing in Civ III that will be better than in the later game. It's only worth playing for saudosism purposes. It's heavily outdated.

Content - 8.5
Steam version is a complete version, which includes both expansion packs released. You have a vast number of civilizations to pick and you can adjust some major settings for a location, like temperature, umidity, geological era, water level, etc. You can also chose the victory conditions for a game, which you can fit into your play style, along with difficulty level. The Civilopedia is a tool of great educational value, it contains real data about the civilizations, technologies, unities and almost everything you can find in the game. There is a highest scores table too, but I believe it only displays single-player scores. I don't know if steam is providing some sort of multiplayer support at this time.

Gameplay - 4.0
Like most Civ games, you start with a settler, a worker and/or a warrior in most cases, from this you have to build your city and administer it's growth with the resources gathered around it, which can be selected in the city radius. Each unity you create in a city has a better use, and through the years (turns), as long as your cities and citizens are productive you'll eventually discover technologies which improve your unities and your cities buildings. You can focus your whole civilization in a few aspects or diversify your knowledge. Every civilization on the map have it's own personality and choices, from warmongers to pacifists. What you have to do is to secure your civilization a place in history. But why I give 4.0? It won't help you get started at all. I'm not asking for a strategy guide, I just wanna learn the basics of the game, what's unique to it, what options I have and what they do. I couldn't find a tutorial or at least a checkbox to display tooltips, even the options in the main menu don't have a basic description. It's one of the less intuitive game I've ever seen, unlike it's predecessor ou sucessor. Of course after sometime you'll start to get used to the controls, but they still feel weird. The UI is not friendly even for games older than it is, Age of Empires II is older and has a much more friendly interface and controls.

Graphics - 2.5
The game looks very bad even for its generation, Age of Wonders and Medieval Total War had much better visual quality. Civilization III looks so bad that if affects gameplay, you need to often take a closer look to identify some terrains and unities. There are no options for good graphic enhancements, you can not adjust resolution, it's based on desktop resolution, and even tweaking can't get satisfactory results. I know it's an old game, but the ones I cited are old too and are from the same genre. At least the game showed an improvement compared to the previous title, texture quality is better and there are movement animations for the unities.

Overall - 5.8

Current specs
Intel Core I7-4770K at 4.2ghz
Nvidia PNY GTX 770 2gb at 1201mhz
Kingston HyperX DDR3 8gb at 1600mhz (x2)
HP 1TB SATA III 7200rpm
Windows 7 Premium SP1
Sony Bravia KDL-42W655A at 1080p

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Are you looking for a Time sink?

Here you are!

This is a basic turned based Real Time Strategy game based around building a civilation from a tribal state to a modern age.

The Charm of this game really comes from your opponates, how they'll mock you, or try to threaten you to give them what they want. You can completely civil, or you can be a thorn in everyone's side, which can get to the point of the entire planet trying to destroy you.

A problem is that the mechanics can be confusing, heck it took me a solid three hours of reading to get a basic grasp on the game. but once you learn it, it's down, and it become second nature.

Another problem, if you can call it one, is that this game will burn hours of your life without your consent, seriously, you will play 4 hours stright and swear it was maybe 30 minutes.

8/10 
PROS:
Great RTS game play
Aged nicely
great freedom to choose

CONS:
Quite a few things to learn to even start playing
Will sink hours without you knowing it.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: The franchise is run through to the bitter end, with players opting for piracy and spacecraft without help or hail-mary, as the plot devolves unerringly to next advances in technology. The tech tree from Civilization II carried the throne room. In Civ III, the multiplayer and marginalised are in an open door to cultural centres around the world, egging on the tech-savvy, New York hipster, python coding sky rise. The introduction is the selling point. Closing on the propogandist last installment, Civilization V: Brave New World. Not everyone knows, but Huxley's Brave New World Revisited is a non-fiction debacle couched in a comfortable sequel for bugs from early adolescence to young adulthood. The gateway to television since Iraq is clouded by war still now, and today, a friendly reminder of our spiritual needs as anthropogists is as healthy as any Black Sabbath. Drugs tear families apart. But babies need drugs to grow. Weather control is a superpower. I recommend frequent save games with a friend

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: This phenomenal strategy game is mentally stimulating and epic, though I will admit it might not be very rewarding. Standard games usually took me days, and each of the hourse you're playing requires you be goal-oriented and considerate. Strategic resources, oceans and capturable units can be a pain, but I recommend this game to those who have a lot of free time. I suggest choosing small maps and few rivals.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I love this game. Out of any of the Civ games, it is, in my opinion, the one with the best sense of scale. The combat is slightly unbalanced (Memetic mutation of a spearman beating a tank, after all...) and the interface isn't as perfected as in Civ 4, but these issues come up less often than you think. Its editor is simple to use and its modding community is huge even after all these years (possibly even the largest of the series from what I've seen). You can find mods and extremely well-done player-made campaigns about everything from the Reconquista and the Punic Wars to the Portuguese Colonial War. I especially recommend Age of Imperialism (the mod), and Escape from Zombie Island is another gem that shows just how much can be done with the game's relatively simple editor, completely transforming a game about empire-building into a game about zombie survival. But to be honest, even the vanilla, unmodded game is a blast to play and never really gets old.

In short, this is a game with endless value and honestly $5 is a steal. It's something I never get bored of and always come back to binge on every month or so. Fantastic game, a masterpiece. My favorite in the series, though I like 4 and 5 too.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Dont trust the one line fanboy reviews. This entire series is one those emperors new clothes type of games. No one wants to say how crap it really is because its a 'classic'. 

There is no strategy involved. It really doesnt matter what you do. You wait for your advisor to tell you what to build and you click ok. The game is very buggy. A strange glitch produces seven of your main characters eg 7 Queen elizabeths. It randomly crashes when attacking a city. 

The 'city view' has to be the single most pointless thing I have seen in any game. An identical view for each city that is of no use whatsoever. 

The cartoonish attempt at humour is just embarrasing and ruins the feel of the more serious stuff like the scientific research, that would have been interesting if it was more detailed. The AI are not funny or clever for that matter. 

If you like strategy and history this will not challenge you in any way, maybe get it for your kid?

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: My first real video game, being brought up on all those educational "Leap Start" games from way back when, never getting any real games until this one, I loved it from the very first turn. This game is quite possibly one of the best strategy games ever created. It has perfect balance, great gameplay, its very hard to win but you still have fun with it because of the flawless design, the units are all unique and each one is cool in its own way, from the days of stones and swords to fighter jets and skyscrapers, you'll have fun forever. I still remember my first victory, so many years later. I remember just how proud I was, looking at all those beat up other leaders, mine staring at them with a shit faced grin of complete pompus superiority, I felt like I was god. When you actually win, which I've only done once, it feels SO FUCKING GOOD. You feel like you just took over the world in real life, especially with all the other leaders sitting there, cowering before your might! Its just awesome, please please buy this game, it is a classic that will never die, and everyone should get it, try it at least once. 9001/10
