title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: This is my favorite civ game by far. Civ V is great and all, but my biggest complaint about it is that you can only have like 20 nukes tops. Civ III lets you have as many as you so desire. Plus, you get ICBMs (as many as you want)! Civ V doesn't let you have ICBMs. However, in Civ III, I've got ICBMs in at least 20-30 cities, tactical nukes everywhere, subs (with tacticals) spread all across the map targeting all coastal and inner coastal cities. I can start WWIII any time I want, and I can be sure that I will have no shortage of nukes. Plus just painting some island in that b, e, a, utiful orange coat is just a pleasure. Get Civ III, don't waiste your money on Civ V.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
The game is old. The game is definetly recomented from my part.

I had to lower the screen resolution to avoid the 'tiny-litle-units' making my ayes go into pain. :-) But after all these years, I really enjoyed again the struggle to build a sivilization. There are newer versions of the same game nowdays. But I really believe that each of the Civilization games has its unique satisfaction to offer the strategy gamer, even if Civ IV is my prefered one.

I definetly recoment CIV III, especially moded with mods like "Rise And Rule", which add many new units, technologies etc.  The problem is, I can not clearly identify what is this 'different gameplay aspects' that kept me playing CIV II all these hous and not starting a CIV IV or CIV V campain... The differenses on units, wonders, railway inprovements etc, should not be enouph to get me playing a game as old as this one... On the other hand, I got myself missing the real-movie councelors of CIV-II, but I don't think I will play that old love again :-)

In any case. Considering the very low price that you can purchse this old game (Civilization III), especially in a bountle together with the newet versions, I definetly believe that any gamer that likes turn -base build-expand strategies should give it a try. Even for the shenarios of the 'complete' edition, a CIV-V fun could find in CIV-III a way to further expand his Civilization gamepleasure.

Have a good game everyone :-)

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
My friend introduced me to this game a long time ago, and I can't thank him enough! although I only have 2 hours on the steam version I happily spent hundreds ( at least) on the disc version he loaned me ( back when you could do that). 
   But anyway the reason your reading this is to learn weather or not this game is worth 5 bucks to buy. To answer that you must ask  yourself some questions.
1) do you like running your own country and mercilessly clicking other countries to death?
2) do you like exploring randomly generated worlds and clicking other countries to death?
3) do you like sending hundreds of units at enemys to make them fight to the death with other countries units by clicking?
4) do you enjoy classical music while clicking other countires to death?
5) do you care that there are 3 newer versions of the game?

If you answered yes to 1-4 and no to 5 BUY THE GAME
If you answered yes to 5 don't buy the game you nostalgia hater
If you answered no to 5 and yes to 3 of the first 4 questions then BUY THE GAME
If you answered no to 5 and yes to 2 of the first 4 questions you may want to consider waiting untill the game goes on sale
If you answered no to 5 and yes to 1 of the first 4 questions you may be looking at the wrong genre of games 
If you answered yest to 5 and no to the first 4 questions you ARE looking at the wrong genre of games

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
(ignore how long it says I've played; I got this game when it first came out for MacOS 9, and actually have a couple hundred hours sunk into it.)

This is the first Civ game I've ever played, and even after IV and V, it's still my favorite. There are a number of wonderful features that don't exist in the later games that I miss whenever I play them (palaces, roads across mountains, subtle references to Civ I bugs, actual in-depth physical documentation, etc). If you can stand the dated graphics and hard-to-set-up multiplayer, it's a 10/10. If you can't, it's a 10/10. Get this game. It's so good.

Rating: 10/10

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Vincent Price's most helpful reviews: Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete. 



Civilization III (or Civ III for short) is an argricultural war simulator, in which you build wheat, farm iron, and thresh people in a significant battle over land and cities.


Should you take too long to murder your foes, the game may decide to just let you win by saying you're so cultural that there's no way they can challenge you, and they automatically forefeit. Which is stupid, because a rich culture like that is not as likely to have the vast killing potential an uncultured brutish army nation would, but alas, not everything in life, or Civ, is logical.



10/10 with a friend, 6/10 by yourself, 2/10 when you spend hours trying to port forward to get it to work properly on multiplayer. Recommended for people who want their lives consumed entirely.

review: Civ3 is the best turn-based strategy game ever!  I originally bought this game when it was released in 2001 and I still play it in 2014. The graphics are dated and 2D but that isn't really a bad thing because this game isn't about eye candy; it's about strategy.  This is definately a niche game and not going to be for everyone.  If you are a fan of turn based war games then you must give this a try.  The game starts slow but before you know it you are hooked.

In conclusion, good game. Up until you meet someone else

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I played this game way back in 2001. The problem I faced was at that time, I had an ancient Pentium II 300Mhz PC. So you can imagine how I felt as the game was nearly unplayable for me.

Coming into the present time of 2014, I was glad that Steam offered Civilization III for sale. I quickly bought it and played on my modern top of the line laptop. It sure brought back the memories. 

This game can be considered a classic in the turn based strategy (TBS) genre. TBS fans would most definitely love this game despite the dated graphics. I must also like to add that the Steam version of the game works perfectly fine in Windows 8.1. A TBS haven to say the least!

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
I purchased this game in order to understand and have an enlightenment on the essential game mechanics of the Civilization game series. I am still not sure whether Civilization III was the right choice.

Here are a few topics that I wish to highlight:
- It is a low-paced, turn-based strategy game with a significant amount of historical content.
- There are a few variables in the game that the person should learn before starting to play. Luckily, steam provides us with a manual, so DO read it.
- For beginners, this game may become tough, even at the lowest difficulty setting. Even after learning the basics, there are many things one can do wrong.
- This game can take MANY hours of your time, and once your civilization has more than 10 settlements, it may take more than a minute to play each game turn. In addition, there may be dozens and dozens of turns before a victory condition is met.
- Although it DOES seem to work on my Windows 8.1 machine, there are a few frustrating issues, such as window switching not restoring the original resolution until the game is terminated. Also, the game may occasionally crash on some particular user, and so far it has always crashed after the end of a game. This means that the game could have had a better preparation for modern systems.

Therefore, it is both hard to recommend and unrecommend this game. Take this as a midline evaluation. If you have time to spare, go ahead and give it a try. Or who knows, the other games in the series might be more interesting.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: I own both Civ III and Civ V and I would say that I enjoy Civ III more. It has a much easier learning curve than Civ V and I find it all around easier as well, plus some nice retro graphics and a very enjoyable soundtrack. My gradfather gave me vanilla Civ III and I got hours and hours of gameplay out of it, then I decided to buy the complete version on steam, and let me tell you, it DOUBLES the content of the original game. For the low price of $4.99 (and occasionally lower) I definatly recomend it. Fair waring though, in all of my games with the french as my competitors, I can safely say that they are giant, self-rightous ass holes. Never make deals with them.

review: Civ 3 has kinda been forgotten now with Civ 4 and Civ 5 out, but it remains my favourite. Whilst I can't think of anything in particualar that it did better (other than the attack/defense of troops instead of some weird strength system that makes no sense and a clear hit point bar showing you how much health your troops have left) the overall feel of this game (and it's soundtrack!) make for the most fun out of the 3 games (3, 4 and 5) that I have played. Civ 3 was the first game of the series I played and so there may be a lot of bias based on nostalgic value here, but I still highly reccomend this game to any strategy fan.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
OKay, First off, this may be a little biased as Civ 3 was the game that introduced me to the franchise. That said, It' s a solid 4X title, Graphically, it's obviously not going to be State of the Art, but I've never found that to matter with this genre; and apparently neither have most people given that one of the most popular 4X games around is Alpha Centari, which came out in 1999. 

Sorry, got a bit off topic.

Like all the Civ games, Civilization 3 puts you in control of a settler and warrior, kicks you into the oceon that is its game play and tells you to swim. The tutorial is there, but it's basically a series of tips that pop up when you start doing things. well written and concise, but they don't force your hand. Also like the other Civ games, there is a large tech tree and ages to advance through as your empire grows. The main appeal of the game is that no two playthroughs [which can take weeks to months if you play casually] are ever going to be the same. One game History may play out as you destroy the Aztecs as the Spanish... but in the next game, Gahndi might nuke your American ass into oblivion. 

Ultimately, 4X games aren't for everyone, but everyone should give the genre a try and at the price they're asking for it, Civ 3 is an affordable, still good looking, and complete introduction to the genre as well as a game that experienced players will enjoy for years to come.

[[A note on the CIv Franchise: those of you who started civ with 4 or 5 should also give 3 a try, the three titles are honestly different enough that they could be said to be equally good in their own right, assuming of course that you have the DLC for Civ 5, otherwise.... *shudders*]]

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Let me say that this was my first Civilization game, and for being on sale for $5, I am sure I would buy the game again.

If you're new or interested in Civilization games, I HIGHLY recommend reading further and/or watching videos to understand what you are getting into:

Pros-

This game is highly detailed and allows for a significant amount of strategy-management decisions. Learning the system and "how to beat it" itself was an enjoyable that I still can't fully claim to have achieved.

Cons-

There is no help in-game in actually learning the game. This will either add hours of patience in learning the game, or frustration.

The computer AI is abhorrent for trading.

Fair Warning: This game is SLOW. I am okay about slow games, when I am mentally prepared for it. This game is so slow, whether due to micromanagement, organizing your thoughts, or constant unit/city decisions. In my opinion, the pacing of this game is not evidence of a detailed well thought out game (which yes, it is), but of a poorly designed game. Even in "speed-mode"...just ugh, it's still slow.


I suggest that if you are interested in a strategic, decision-making game, and ok with long games, the Civilization games will suit your needs. Furthermore, I suggest looking into Galactic Civilizations, at the least for the sake of a real tutorial.

Again, if you're new to these games, do your research and check out other people's opinions before diving into the Civilization world.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: Many believe this to be the best Civilization game in the series, and I have to agree. No other Civ has the same amount of sheer content as this one: From civs to leaders, buildings, wonders, scenarios, you name it. Also, the leader's personalities shine, and the diplomacy system is much deeper than in the newer iterations, you can basically tell Ghandi to go fuck himself if he pisses you off. In general, the game is deeper than both its successors, but the tutorial does a good job of teaching you the basics. The rest can be learned through experience. The only thing that I feel could turn someone off is the graphics, which look a bit outdated by now, but if you're willing to look past the surface, hours upon hours of fun await.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
For a game made all the way back in October 2001, this is a fantastic game.

First off, if you bought Civilization Revolution for the Xbox 360 or iPad, that is nothing compared to this old but fantastic game.
Secondly, make sure you play this when you havn't got anything else to do in the next 24 hours because this game takes some time and patients and you are guranteed to get 100% addicted.
However, if you want to go online, nobody will be on there and if you host a server nobody will join (unless, of course, one of your friends have the game and you invite them). Also, on your first game you ever play, make sure you make it so it's on the easiest difficulty and do a little amount of Civilizations otherwise you will get brutally battered like a Cod fish.

10 features Civilization 3 has that Civilization Revolution Doesn't

1. You can alter the map size between Tiny and Huge.
2. You can alter the settings on how to win the game.
3. The Middle Age is included.
4. You get workers to build Outposts, Mines, Barricades, Irrigation (farm/food resources) etc.
5. There is more research.
6. More units.
7. Create your own map in the editor.
8. Edit the map properties.
9. More Civilizations.
10. More Civilizations allowed to be active in game.

Keep in mind that Civilization Revolution is newer than Civilization 3.
I can't really think of anything you can't do in Civilization 3 that you can in Civilization Revolution.
I cannot compare Civilization 3 to Civilization 2, 4 and 5 as I do not have those and I have never played them. I would assume that Civilization 4 and 5 are better though.
I completely reccomend this game and I'd say it is still a brilliant game now in 2014 and that takes a lot for a game to be that good!

Hope this makes you want to buy Civilization 3 because it deserves more buyers. This game is also very handy if you have have a bad Graphics Card and Processor like my computer. When it says it runs on Windows XP only it really means Windows XP or better. Happy Gaming!

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
This game was my first TBS. A guy I worked with talked about it, and I bought it. This was a few months before Civ IV came out.  I became a bit obsessed. We even had a play-by-email game going for a while. 

I have no idea how many hours I put into it, but it was a lot. I think I've bought it three times since then. I still love the game. I'm far more likely to play Civ V now, but I just like knowing that Civ III is there, any time I want to play it. Civ III was my gateway game to AoE, RoN, AoM... all of which I have also bought multiple times and currently have installed on my computer.

Yes, most of my warm fuzzy feelings may be simply nostalgia, but I do think the game still has a lot to offer.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Well I was hoping for a different experience from Civ IV.  I was hoping that Civ IV was that point where the devs went through a 'lets temporarily sell out and fuck up the franchise for a while' phase, but it turns out Civ III is shitty as well.

Okay, it's not as silly as Civ IV.  In may ways, I still despise Civ IV, but I'll admit it's a nitpick.  I'd give it the same rating otherwise, because it's almost the same game.  Civ IV's interpretation of religion is silly.  Read the other review for more about that.

Okay, enough about fucking Civ IV, lets talk about Civ III.  But what is there to talk about really?  I tried to have fun, but it was the dullest 5 hours on chieftain (easiest difficulty) of moving around a bunch of soldiers and workers (that's all this game is, soldiers and workers and building ROADS) with the scandinavian vikings that I used to conquer the Aztec empire (ultimately a game of city tag), while fending off Japanese and Romans, I've ever had.  Eventually, I resigned, because Sumeria was really big, Persia entered a 'golden age', and I had to end it at some point.

There was no way to end this game properly without playing for another 8 hours, and that was a standard size map.  The one thing I sorta appreciated was how the enemy leaders poke fun at you for quitting.  The victory screen scores, such as 'children per family', 'population', and 'average lifespan', are mostly purely for flair and meaningless.  

Final Score - 38/100

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
If you love the wargame aspect of the CIVILIZATION games, this game still has a lot to offer.  I put in a lot of hours in the last two weeks.  Domination games ran about 48 hrs on the lowest setting, longer at higher settings where one must think more about each move, for those who like to micromanage....keep cranking up the difficulty level.   Sorry, CIV I and II fans.  No more Diplomat units.  A very different experience than CIV IV, which became awesome with all the fine mods available.  I admit. This game hits my Turn-Based-Strategy  sweet spot for kicking back and wargaming.  One of the best "old" computer games I bought in the last year, not because I did not have it already; because for $5 I got to play an apparently bug  free game inside of 5 minutes on Windows 7 and no making it run on a VM virtual machine.  Gets my Happy Camper award.

MAJOR IRRITATING PROBLEM:  From the origional, after a unit moves, the game jumps to the next (not nearest) unit that may be half a world away.  There is no way to stop and look at what your just-moved unit saw without scrolling to find it.  This becomes very irritating after a while.  I had forgotten about it.  It is not a bug, it is programming design.  This got fixed in later games so the game paused after each unit moves, allowing you to stay in an area and complete a battle before moving on by hitting a key when YOU are ready.  Think of a scar on Mona Lisa's face.   Think of a good movie that periodically stutters, jumps or freezes.   Oh, wait.  I already have that.  Verison FIOS, may the gods bless their awesome up and download speeds.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Civilization 3 is the third installement in the popular turn-based strategy series and personally my favorite. 

First of all this title still holds up tremendously well nowadays, it runs on newer operation systems and you can tweak the resolution in a file making the game really great to play. There aren't any issues at all.

Civ3 is not as complex as Civ4 and doesn't have such intricate indepth mechanics but still manages to keep the player busy, you have to manage several aspects of your empire. The more streamlined gameplay makes this Civilization my favorite, it's easy to understand but yet very hard to master. You get down the basics really fast but in order to be good at it, you need some serious practise. There are tons of different civilizations to choose from and many different scenarios. The included expansion offer even more content. The AI is really good and easily challenge you, even on lower difficulties. 

The visuals are also nicely presented, the 2d sprites look good and have a more realistic touch. The soundtrack and soundassets are also amazing and do a great job immersing yourself into the game.

Overall this is just an well designed game and incredibly enjoyable. I recommend this game a lot.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Having played Civilization 2-5, as well as the games made by the original team of Civilization : Call to Power 1&2,
I would say ANY Civilization game so far is a buyer and a keeper, if you are into turn based strategy games.
The only reason Civilization 1 is missing from my collection is the rareness of finding someone having and willing to sell his/her copy, I woud jump at the change;)

every Civ Game adds a little and removes a little, the one that you like most is personal flavour.
To me this one certainly ranks higher than the later Civ 4 and 5.
This game was and is the height of "classic" Civilization games.

For you people ariving at this from Civ 2 : you only will miss the old advisors (civ 5 and they still not have returned them sadly enough)
For you people ariving at this from Civ 4 and 5 : no religion, but instead you will love the stacks of doom, army units, and other things that were removed in later game.

This game is also somewhat older and a lot lighter on system requirements than later civ games, making it great to play on any device you want to. Also for a mere 4.99 (and it's often on sale for 2.49, and more rare for 1.25) you have an asolute bargain!

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
The third installment in the Civilization series which is getting pretty old these days, with it's successor Civilization IV and V.  This is another one of those titles that you might have grown up with as a kid and have had nostalgic value to you. This is at least the case for me. I remember that the game took a chocking 700 MB of space on my hard disk and it was generally tanking my late 90's computer. I have sunk a huge amount of hours into this game and for me this is the best game in the series.

Civilization is probably the most dominating Turn-based strategy game in the gaming industry. The Total Wars games for example are RTS/TBS hybrids, while CIV is completely TBS. True Civilization enthusiasts probably rank Civ3 pretty low, compared to Civ2, Civ4 and Civ5 which were very well received for their times. For me however, Civilization 3 is the favorite among the ones I've played (Civ3, Civ4 and Civ5). Again - because of it's nostalgic value.

All Civ games start out the same way unless you play a scenario or campaign. You start off with a settler and a warrior of some sorts. The settler can build a city, and as you find a suitable location for your capital - let your Civilization begin! Beware though, once you have started a game you won't be able to leave for at least 4 hours. This game is honestly best played during the night and is mostly a single-player experience.

There is a Campaign/Scenario mode, where you play historical events or just silly settings. As well as a multiplayer mode, but I have never enjoyed these ones at all. Nothing beats that random map mode, select the terrain, the climate, map size and your opponents/allies. Let the history get rewritten as you choose the path of the righteous, or the path of the tyrant. Through exploding expansion, racing technology, crushing warfare and cunning diplomacy you must stand victor as the one and only dominating superpower.

[b]I only recommend picking this up if you have a personal connection to it, or if you are entirely out of gameplay from modern titles.[/b]

[u]Note: You might want to check out [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/8930/]Civilization V[/url] ([url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/mendozacheers/recommended/8930/]Review[/url]) as it's a modern take to the genre and series.[/u]

I spent so many hours in this game when it wasn't on Steam. I'd play the same world for what would be milleniums in game time, creating an absolutely massive empire only for Gandhi to nuke it all to dust. It's five dollars, so it's definitely worth the price now.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete

Bear in mind that the AI is not as sophisticated as most would like - the computer controlled opponents will gang up on you for no reason. However, this game is well worth the low price of $5. A physical copy at Wal-Mart will still set you back $10.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III, the sequel to the great Civilization II, a game that by some is still to this day considered to be the best of the series, has the heavy duty challenge of not only living up to the standards set by it's predecessors but also to innovate the franchise enough that players of the previous installment can be bothered to upgrade.

It starts out with a somewhat mixed feeling. Some of the great ideas from Alpha Centauri has been brought over creating a much more versatile playing field with a living map and more unique factions but many of Alpha Centauri's greatest assets, such as the ability to build your own units and terrain elevations are notably absent. and others, such as unique factions, are only half implemented.

These improvements however do still manage to increase the interactivity of the game substantially particularly when combined with the many new features, such as culture, that Civ III brings to the table.

Factions are not longer defined simply by their city names but now have a few unique units of little consequence and civilization traits of great consequence. Unique units are simply beefed up versions of regular units that give a faction a small military advantage during the time period in which the unit is present, this can be a nice boost if you happen to go to war in that time but it can also be ignored completely if the time for war is not right. The traits each faction receives now however are of a much greater importance and can range from getting a free technology every age to a half off cost on religious buildings. These traits are big enough in effect that they tend to define your entire game.

A new and important feature in Civ III is culture. Each city generates culture through it's various buildings and the culture in turn defines the size of it's borders. A heavily cultured city can even envelop the city of an opponent and flip it to your side. While the realism or historical accuracy of such a device is laughable at best it does provide players with a new means of expansion and a way to deal with those pesky resource stealing late game cities that the AI is so fond of placing in whatever unoccupied corner of your empire it can find.

Graphically Civilization III is passable as always, the city view is pleasant but the rest of the game gives only a mediocre visual experience. Nothing pretty but nothing that'll ruin your gaming experience either. The soundtrack is still mostly orchestral epics and works very well although the rest of the sound effects in the game are pretty forgettable.

All in all Sid Meier's Civilization III is a good sequel. It doesn't create quite the same feeling of amazement and enjoyment that going from Civ I to Civ II does but it manages to provide a good solid experience with enough innovation to justify the purchase.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: I didn't give this game a fair try back in the days when it was new.  The game was visually an improvement over Civ II, and the interface was actually functional.  I just felt the combat system was poorly done, diplomacy didn't feel right, and the game has a few design quirks.  Fast forward to now, I decided to buy the complete edition, which updates the game.  What I find now is a game that truly stands between the majesty of Civ II and Civ IV.  The Civ experience is there, and it's well represented.  The graphics haven't aged all that well, and the interface isn't as nice as the later games, but the gameplay remains classic Civ.  The complete edition adds the feature of customizing the game in ways never seen before or again in a Civ game, such as turning down (or up) AI aggression.  It is a good, cheaper entry into the world of Civ.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® III Complete
review: The best of the franchise.  I started playing the original shortly after it came out, it blew my mind.  CIV2 made minor enhancements, but was largely the same game.  The first time I played CIV3, I hated it.  The strategies I had developed for 1&2 no longer worked (the catapult is quite different, for example) and it took me a few minutes to grok the culture concept.  Once I did (and learned the unit differences), I never went back.  The AI is sooo much better than before and unlike CIV4 (which despite buying and forcing myself to play, I never enjoyed), you still get to micromanage a great deal (but you can also automate quite a bit - the ability to choose is awesome).  Buy it on sale if new to the franchise & start with a tiny world.  If you are used to another CIV game, don't wait for a sale, buy it now & get to know the differences in the tech tree as well as the unit differences - I bet you'll like it!
